title: McCann v. Doe
description: In this adoption case, the prospective adoptive parents appeal the family court's decisions:  (1) to revoke the biological mother's consent for adoption, finding the consent was involuntary; and (2) to return the child to the biological mother.  We affirm, finding there was evidence to support the biological mother's claim of involuntariness and the best interest of the child would then be with the biological mother.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

				Laura McCann, Respondent,
				v.

JUSTICE BEATTY:Â  In this adoption case, the prospective adoptive parents,
  John and Jane Doe, appeal the family courtâ€™s orders:Â  (1) revoking Laura
  McCannâ€™s (the biological motherâ€™s) consent for adoption because it was
  involuntarily entered; and (2) finding the revocation of the consent would be
  in the best interest of the child and placing the child back with McCann.Â  We
  note both the Does and McCann love and take excellent care of the child.Â 
  However, our review of the evidence supports the family courtâ€™s decision to
  revoke McCannâ€™s consent to adopt and to return the child to McCann.Â   
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On the afternoon of Wednesday, July 19,
  2006, thirty-year-old McCann drove herself to Hilton Head Regional Medical Center while in labor.Â  At the time, McCann had several emotional stressors in her
  life, including:Â  (1) her boyfriend had died tragically in a car accident two
  years prior; (2) her father had died from pancreatic cancer the prior year; (3)
  the pregnancy was the result of a rape; (4) she hid her pregnancy from her
  mother, sister, friends, and coworkers because she was ashamed and afraid of
  their reaction; and (5) she had lost her job during her pregnancy when the restaurant
  she managed closed down.Â  Although McCann initially informed the hospital staff
  that she had prenatal care in New York, she later admitted she had not had
  prenatal care.Â  McCann indicated on the hospital intake forms that she:Â  had a
  bachelorâ€™s degree; worked as a waitress; was of Catholic faith; did not have
  plans to place the child for adoption; and desired contact with the child.Â  She
  did not have anyone with her during her delivery and did not want anyone called
  on her behalf.Â   
McCann delivered a healthy baby girl
  around 5:00 p.m. that same day.Â  However, McCann did not respond to the child,
  touch the child, or look at her when the child was placed on McCannâ€™s chest.Â 
  McCann did not want to see the child later in the nursery.Â  Nurse Wendy Yemec thought
  McCannâ€™s flat response to the baby was not normal, and the treating
  obstetrician ordered a social work consult.Â  McCann was very tearful and
  remained so for the rest of her hospital stay.
On Thursday, July 20, 2006, McCann had
  several evaluations.Â  Dr. Ann Gorman, the obstetrician in charge of post-partum
  care, noted McCann was tearful and learned of McCannâ€™s stressors.Â  McCann briefly
  mentioned adoption to Dr. Gorman.[1]Â  Although she did not diagnose McCann with post-partum
  depression, Dr. Gorman was concerned that McCann did not have any apparent
  support system, believed McCann might be at risk for post-partum depression,
  and ordered a psychiatric consultation with Dr. Srivastava.Â   
That same morning, Judy Hewes[2] performed the social work evaluation on
  McCann to determine what kind of support system McCann had and what kind of
  prenatal care McCann had been given.Â  The two discussed the stressors in
  McCannâ€™s life and Hewes provided McCann with names and telephone numbers of
  adoption agencies per McCannâ€™s request.Â  Hewes informed McCann that she had
  positive experiences with adoption because two of her siblings were adopted.
 
Hewesâ€™ conversation with McCann was
  interrupted when Dr. Srivastava entered the room to perform a psychological
  evaluation.Â  The examination was for the sole purpose of determining whether
  McCann required further hospitalization for psychological issues due to her
  incessant crying; he did not evaluate McCann for the purpose of determining
  whether she could knowingly and intelligently consent to the relinquishment of
  her child for adoption.Â  After speaking with McCann for less than an hour, Dr.
  Srivastava determined that, although she had significant stressors in her life,
  she did not have significant depression requiring hospitalization.Â  He
  recommended follow-up therapy without medication.Â  Dr. Srivastava diagnosed
  McCann with â€œsignificant adjustment disorder,â€ between anxiety and depression,
  with a functioning level, or GAF score of 50, which meant partial insight.Â 
  Although he noted that a GAF score of below 50 would require hospitalization,
  he testified that â€œpartial insightâ€ meant fair insight within the normal range
  and not significantly impaired.Â  He stated the diagnosis of adjustment disorder
  did not impair judgment.Â  Although McCann did not discuss adoption in detail,
  she told Dr. Srivastava she was considering adoption, she would â€œfeel ok about
  it,â€ and she did not have enough resources to care for a baby.Â  Dr. Srivastava
  testified he did not think social stressors would generally affect decision
  making, and he had no concerns about McCannâ€™s ability to make decisions.Â  Dr.
  Srivastava did not diagnose McCann with post-partum depression because the
  illness does not generally manifest until some time after delivery, and he did not
  see signs of post-partum depression in McCann.Â  According to Dr. Srivastava,
  McCann was initially tearful during their meeting, she smiled at times, and she
  was able to engage in the conversation and was not tearful by the end.Â   
In the afternoon on July 20th, McCann
  referred to a business card given to her along with the list of adoption agency
  names she requested from Hewes, and she called Helen Duschinski, director of A
  Childâ€™s Future Adoptions, a private adoption agency based in Aiken, South Caroli  na.Â  McCann testified that she was just exploring options, but Duschinski
  stated McCann informed her that she had a baby that she wanted to give up for
  adoption and wanted to know whether there was a family with which the child
  could be placed.Â  Duschinski agreed to meet with McCann the next morning at the
  hospital in Hilton Head, and Duschinski contacted the Does about the baby.Â  At
  some point, Nurse Yemec came in the room and overheard McCann on the phone with
  Duschinski.Â  Yemec hugged McCann and told her how unselfish and brave she was
  being in making the adoption decision.Â  McCann requested to see the baby for
  the first time the evening of July 20th, and the baby stayed in the room with
  her, for the most part, until discharge the next day.Â  McCann appeared to bond
  with her baby.Â   
On the morning of Friday, July 21, 2006, Duschinski got
  lost on her way to the hospital, McCann called her to find out why she was
  late, and McCann gave Duschinski directions to the hospital.Â  Duschinski
  testified McCann was clearly resolved in her decision to give the baby up for
  adoption, and never verbalized any doubts, citing the fact that she was single
  and there were societal and financial pressures associated with raising a
  baby.Â  However, McCann denied having made up her mind about adoption when she
  called Duschinski, but she did not know whether she had told Duschinski she
  wanted to put her child up for adoption.Â  McCann believed Duschinski worked
  with the Department of Social Services and would explain the process.Â  Duschinski
  filled out paperwork, including medical and family history.Â  One of the
  documents Duschinski had McCann sign regarded counseling and stated, â€œI
  acknowledge that counseling is available to me and has been offered to me.Â  Iâ€™m
  aware that counseling will be made available to me should I request it during
  this pregnancy or within two weeks after delivery.â€Â  Duschinski testified
  McCann was crying and laughing during their meeting, trying to lighten the room
  with humor.Â  She did not think McCannâ€™s emotional reaction was unusual.Â 
 
At that point, Duschinski left the room
  and the Doesâ€™ attorney, Rick Corley, and attorney Hector Esquivel, the separate
  attorney to present the consent form to McCann, entered the hospital room.Â 
  Corley left as Esquivel went over the consent for adoption form with McCann and
  Hewes remained in the room as a witness.Â  McCann believed he was her attorney,
  although his fees were being paid by the Does.Â  Esquivel testified he went
  through the consent form line by line, trying to ensure that McCann understood
  the form and that her consent was voluntary.Â  He stated she did not appear to
  be in any unusual emotional distress, that she was teary at times, but he
  believed she was comfortable and resolute.Â  McCann was holding the baby during her
  meeting with Esquivel.Â   
Esquivel testified he specifically went
  over the sections regarding the fact that there was no waiting period, that her
  decision was permanent, and that she had no right to rescission like with
  financing agreements.Â  At one point he told her the only way to revoke the
  consent was to go to court and explain the decision was made under duress, but
  Hewes testified he responded to one of her questions by stating that McCann
  could go to court to prove she was the better parent in order to â€œundo it.â€Â 
  Esquivel testified that he told her he would leave if she had any doubts, that
  she could get either legal or other counseling and then decide at a later time
  whether to proceed with the adoption, but McCann did not want counseling and seemed
  to understand the gravity of the situation.Â   
One of the documents Esquivel had McCann
  sign was a medical power of attorney, which stated, â€œthis limited medical power
  of attorney shall expire upon the surrender of my parental rights in a court
  proceeding in accordance with South Carolina law unless I earlier revoke it in
  writing.â€Â  Although McCann testified that she did not listen to what Esquivel
  was saying because she was looking at the baby, she admitted that she was calm
  when she signed the documents.Â  McCann initialed the consent form next to the
  section stating there is no revocation period.Â   
After signing the documents, McCann
  refused additional time with the child and handed the child over to Corley.Â 
  McCann was discharged that same Friday afternoon, drove herself home, and slept
  for over a day.Â  Both Nurse Yemec and Hewes were so concerned about McCannâ€™s
  emotional well-being that they separately attempted to call her at her house.Â 
  On Monday, July 24, 2006, McCann eventually contacted Hewes, who was afraid
  that McCann might be suicidal.Â  McCann told Hewes that she had contacted the
  adoption agency because she had changed her mind.Â  Duschinski, however,
  testified that McCann only contacted her about â€œsome doubtsâ€ and never
  indicated she wanted to revoke her consent.Â   
The adoptive parents filed a petition for
  adoption on July 26, 2006.Â  McCann filed a Petition for Reversal of Consent on
  July 27, 2006.Â  An emergency hearing was held on August 16, 2006, and the
  family court ordered appointment of Diane Dewitt as guardian ad litem for the
  baby.Â  McCann amended her complaint, and another temporary hearing was held on
  September 21, 2006.Â  At that point, the family court granted McCann limited,
  supervised visitation with the baby.Â Â   
The parties agreed to bifurcate the trial
  to first deal with the issue of voluntariness of the consent and then to deal
  with whether revocation of the consent would be in the best interest of the
  child.Â  On March 1, 2007, the family court issued an order in the first portion
  of the trial.Â  The family court found that, considering McCannâ€™s obvious
  emotional distress, she could not have voluntarily given her consent.Â  The
  court found McCann was in an unusual emotional state during her hospital stay,
  the guidance she received during her hospital stay was not objective and
  reflective of a realistic approach to the situation McCann faced, and the
  confusing wording of the counseling form and medical power of attorney form,
  coupled with Hewesâ€™ question to Esquivel, created the impression that McCann
  had time to revoke.Â  The court further found that the totality of the
  circumstances:Â   

	created such pressure or had such
  influence upon Plaintiff that her signing of the document could not have been
  done voluntarily and that her signing was obtained under duress or through
  coercion.Â  I find these circumstances left her with the view that she had no
  reasonable alternative to signing the Consent and Relinquishment and
  practically destroyed her free will and caused her to do an act not of her own
  volition and that her act was not the result of rational judgment on her par.Â Â Â  
	

The court held McCannâ€™s grant of consent
  was not voluntary and ordered that McCann have more visitation with the baby
  pending the outcome of the second part of the trial regarding what was in the
  best interest for the child.Â   
After the hearing on the best interest
  analysis, the family court ordered that it was in the best interest of the
  child for McCannâ€™s consent to be revoked and for the child to be placed with McCann.Â 
  The Court of Appeals granted the Doesâ€™ motion for supersedeas, held a hearing,
  and then issued an order vacating the supersedeas and ordering that the parties
  share custody of the child on a rotating four-day basis.Â  The case is now
  presently before this Court after it was certified from the Court of Appeals.Â 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals concerning adoption
  proceedings, like any appeal from family court, this Court may find the facts
  in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Phillips v. Baker, 284 S.C. 134, 135, 325 S.E.2d 533, 534 (1985) (â€œAn adoption
  proceeding being a matter in equity heard by the trial judge alone, this
  Courtâ€™s scope of review extends to the finding of facts based on its own view
  of the preponderance of the evidence.â€).Â  This broad scope of review does not
  require the Court to disregard the findings of the family court judge, who saw
  and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate their
  credibility.Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 61, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652
  (2006); Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 523, 599 S.E.2d 114, 118 (2004).Â 
  â€œThis degree of deference is especially true in cases involving the welfare and
  best interests of a minor child.â€Â  Morris, 367 S.C. at 61, 624 S.E.2d at
  652.Â  Â Â Â 
I.Â  Voluntariness of Consent
The Does argue the family court erred in finding
  McCannâ€™s consent was involuntary because McCann did not prove duress, coercion,
  or involuntariness; she only proved she changed her mind.[3]Â  The main question in this case is
  whether the totality of the circumstances, including emotional stressors from
  four significant events and McCannâ€™s confusion over the significance of the
  documents she signed, amounts to signing the consent for adoption involuntarily
  or pursuant to duress or coercion.Â   
Initially, we take this opportunity to comment on the
  relinquishment law in this state.Â  Several states, including our neighboring
  states of Georgia and North Carolina, have a time period during which a
  biological parent can revoke their consent to adopt without having to go to
  court to prove involuntariness, duress, or coercion.Â  See Ga. Code Ann.
  Â§ 19-8-9(b) (Supp. 2007) (giving a biological parent a ten-day period within
  which he or she can withdraw the consent for adoption); N.C. Gen. Stat. Â§
  48-3-706(a) (2005) (stating that a relinquishment of a child may be revoked
  within a seven-day period after signing).Â  In the case of a newborn, this
  relinquishment period allows a biological parent, usually the birth mother, to
  contemplate her decision away from the physical and emotional effects of giving
  birth.Â  After the relinquishment period, the law provides that a biological
  parent may not revoke her consent unless she proves to the court that it was
  involuntary or given under duress or pursuant to coercion.Â  See Hicks
    v. Stargel, 487 S.E.2d 428, 429 (Ga. App. 1997) (holding that there was no
  reason to revoke the surrendering parentsâ€™ consent for adoption more than ten
  days after it was given because there was no evidence of fraud, duress, or
  incapacity); N.C. Gen. Stat. Â§ 48-3-707(a)(1) (2005) (holding that a
  relinquishment shall become void if, before entry of the adoption decree, the
  relinquishing parent establishes by clear and convincing evidence that it was
  obtained by fraud or duress). Â Â 
In South Carolina, there is no waiting
  period before a consent to relinquish a child for adoption becomes effective.Â 
  Thus, once a parent signs a consent, there is no contemplation time or waiting
  period during which the consent can be revoked.[4] Â Withdrawal of the consent is not permitted except by court order after notice
  and an opportunity to be heard by all parties, and â€œexcept when the court finds
  that the withdrawal is in the best interests of the child and that the consent
  or relinquishment was not given voluntarily or was obtained under duress or
  through coercion.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1720 (Supp. 2007).Â  The burden is on
  the person seeking to revoke the consent to show the consent was obtained
  involuntarily.Â  See Phillips v. Baker, 284 S.C. 134, 137, 325
  S.E.2d 533, 535 (1985) (finding the biological mother failed to establish she
  executed the consent form under duress).Â   
While an immediately effective consent
  form may be intended to provide assurances to adoptive parents, it does not
  reduce the heartbreak from prolonged litigation when a biological parent later
  changes his or her mind.[5]Â 
  A reflection period, during which biological parents could closely examine
  their decision, would assure adoptive parents that the adoption would likely be
  completed.Â  Although a biological parent could still attempt to revoke consent
  by proving involuntariness, duress, or coercion, in our view, the likelihood of
  a challenge to the consent after reflecting during a revocation period would be
  substantially reduced.Â  However beneficial for both adoptive and biological
  parents a reflection period may be, it is not the current law in this state,
  and we must, therefore, apply the law as it currently stands.[6]Â   
The more traditional attack on the consent
  for relinquishment is that it was given under duress or pursuant to coercion.Â  Duress
  is defined as â€œâ€˜a condition of mind produced by improper external pressure or
  influence that practically destroys the free agency of a party and causes him
  to do an act or form a contract not of his own volition.â€™â€Â  Phillips,
  284 S.C. at 137, 325 S.E.2d at 535 (quoting Cherry v. Shelby Mut. Plate
    Glass & Cas. Co., 191 S.C. 177, 183, 4 S.E.2d 123, 126 (1939)).Â  Duress
  is viewed with a subjective test, looking at the individual characteristics of
  the person allegedly influenced, and duress does not occur if the person has a
  reasonable alternative to succumbing and fails to avail themselves of the
  alternative.Â  Blejski v. Blejski, 325 S.C. 491, 498, 480 S.E.2d 462, 466
  (Ct. App. 1997) (affirming family courtâ€™s finding that wifeâ€™s acceptance of
  settlement agreement was not made under duress where her attorney told her the
  judge was mad at her and she should accept the agreement or face losing custody
  of her children; the Court of Appeals found attorneyâ€™s advice amounted to an
  opinion and wife had the alternative of taking her chances with a trial).Â  
 
Certainly, many people suffer tragedies in their
  personal lives that do not rise to the level of the legal definition of duress.Â 
  In most instances, suffering tragedies prior to having a baby, without more,
  would not render involuntary a decision to relinquish the child for adoption.Â  However,
  duress is only one consideration, and the Court may look to other factors,
  including the totality of the circumstances, in making the voluntariness
  determination.Â  See Johnson v. Horry County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs.,
  298 S.C. 355, 356, 380 S.E.2d 830, 831 (1989) (considering many factors in affirming
  the family courtâ€™s order finding the consent for adoption was entered
  voluntarily and adoption would be in the best interest of the children where
  the birth mother:Â  had an eleventh grade education; was able to understand the
  documents signed; was not under the influence of incapacitating drugs; was not
  in any unusual emotional state; and indicated that her consent was freely given
  and not the product of duress); see also Burnett v. Burnett,
  290 S.C. 28, 30, 347 S.E.2d 908, 909 (Ct. App. 1986) (finding wife entered into
  domestic settlement agreement voluntarily where there was no evidence that she
  â€œwas compelled to enter the agreement as a result of being overreached or
  subjected to any duress, nor is there any evidence that she was not of sound
  mind or under any unusual stress, other than the stress normally attendant to
  the breakup of a marriageâ€).Â   
Turning to the present case, conflicting
  evidence was presented in the portion of the trial regarding voluntariness.Â  McCann
  cried during her testimony, finding the memories painful, but she believed she
  was now emotionally, mentally, and psychologically strong.Â  She stated she did
  not recall the delivery, and her recollection of the events in the hospital was
  very blurry.Â  She denied telling Dr. Srivastava that she was considering
  adoption.Â  According to McCann, social worker Judy Hewes only gave her adoption
  as an option, although Hewes also discussed how her sister handled being a
  single mom.Â  McCann admitted she told Hewes that she felt the baby might be
  better off with another family.Â Â Â Â   
McCann testified that she thought she had
  time to make her final adoption decision because of the language in the
  counseling form indicating she had two weeks and the language in the medical
  power of attorney that it would expire after a formal court hearing.Â  McCann
  admitted that she was calm when she signed the legal documents, that she knew
  adoption was a permanent legal process, and that she had stated in her
  deposition that she knew the consent documents had significant legal
  ramifications, but she stated she felt completely overwhelmed.Â  She testified
  that she contacted Duschinski on Monday, July 24, 2006, stating she wanted the
  child back, and she was told by Duschinski that she had ninety days to take
  legal action.Â  McCann testified that she felt that Hewes, Yemec, and Dushinski
  misguided her, and she admitted that she felt as though her â€œraging hormones,
  lingering pain medication and the unethical treatment of some of the players
  conspired to leadâ€ her to a poor decision.Â   
McCann also presented the testimony of her
  treating psychologist, Dr. Bryant Welch, and her treating psychotherapist,
  Jocelyn Evans.Â  Dr. Welch, who began seeing McCann five weeks after the
  delivery and reviewed her hospital records, opined that McCann did not
  voluntarily give her consent for adoption because:Â  (1) women have widely
  fluctuating emotions postpartum, and the hospital staff all noted McCannâ€™s
  incessant crying; (2) McCann suffered from tremendous stressors, and the
  cumulative effect impaired her functioning; (3) he believed McCannâ€™s GAF score of
  50 indicated impaired functioning; and (4) McCann did not get the help she
  needed from hospital staff, especially Hewes, who was not licensed and only
  promoted adoption.Â  Welch admitted that Dr. Srivastava did not find McCann had
  impaired functioning, but argued that the doctor was not evaluating McCann for
  her ability to sign a consent form.Â   
Jocelyn Evans became McCannâ€™s treating
  psychotherapist some time after McCann filed the underlying action.Â  Evans also
  testified that McCann was incapable of giving her consent and made her decision
  â€œunder duress,â€ because of the emotional trauma from the totality of her
  stressors, she was visibly overwrought, and she was mentally fragile, though
  not mentally impaired.Â  Evans also noted that she believed a woman should not
  make her adoption decision within the first forty-eight hours after birth and
  that Hewes acted unethically in suggesting adoption where McCann had checked
  â€œnoâ€ to the question of adoption in the hospital intake papers.Â   
Finally, the guardian ad litem, Dewitt,
  presented her report, stating that McCann was a fit, educated, and mature
  parent, with support from her mother and sister.Â  Dewitt stated that although
  she was sure the baby had bonded to some extent with the Does, she was
  impressed that the child seemed to immediately recognize McCann upon their
  first visit at eleven weeks.Â  The family court further heard from Dr. Gorman,
  Judy Hewes, Nurse Yemec, Helen Duschinski, and attorneys Corley and Esquivel.Â 
 
Giving great deference to the family courtâ€™s
  credibility determinations of the conflicting evidence in the present case, we
  find there is abundant evidence that McCannâ€™s emotional stressors and suffering
  caused impaired functioning.Â  All of the hospital personnel interacting with
  McCann noted she was extremely tearful during her stay, and Hewes and Yemec
  were so concerned about her safety that they contacted her after she left the
  hospital.Â  Her extreme behavior required a psychological consult to determine
  solely if McCann could care for herself and be released from the hospital.Â  Dr.
  Srivastava did not evaluate McCann for her ability to make the adoption
  decision, and he noted McCann was functioning with only partial insight, as
  indicated by her GAF score of 50.Â  Despite Dr. Srivastavaâ€™s deposition
  testimony that partial insight meant McCann was not significantly impaired, her
  score was one point away from requiring further hospitalization.Â  Further, the
  only persons who actually evaluated McCann for her ability to consent to
  relinquishment, Dr. Welch and Jocelyn Evans, both opined after reviewing all
  the evidence and records in the case that McCann was incapable of giving her
  voluntary consent for adoption at the time she was in the hospital.Â   
Further, while McCann was suffering from impaired
  functioning, she was encouraged by others regarding the adoption decision, she was
  presented with a counseling form that led her to believe she had a two-week
  time period in which to consider the adoption decision,[7] the medical power of attorney form created
  an impression there was a time period before a court terminated her parental
  rights or before her consent was valid, and the attorney obtaining her
  signature made a statement that she would have to prove she was the better
  parent in order to get her child back.Â  Based on the totality of the
  circumstances in this case, we agree with the family court that McCann proved
  her consent for relinquishment was involuntary.Â   
II. Best Interest
The Does also appeal the finding that it was in the best
  interest of the child for the consent to be withdrawn and for the child to be
  awarded to McCann based on the biological connection.Â Â   
As previously discussed, before a biological parent can
  withdraw her consent to adoption, the family court must make a determination
  that withdrawal is in the best interest of the child and that the
  consent was not voluntarily given or was the product of duress or coercion.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§20-7-1720 (Supp. 2007).Â  â€œThe best interest of the child
  remains, always, the paramount consideration in every adoption.â€Â  Dunn v. Dunn, 298 S.C. 365, 367, 380
  S.E.2d 836, 837 (1989); Doe v. Roe, 369 S.C. 351, 371, 631 S.E.2d 317,
  328 (Ct. App. 2006) (noting that the best interest of the child is the ultimate
  consideration).Â  The state also recognizes a rebuttable presumption in custody
  matters that it is the best interest for the child to be placed with a
  biological parent over a third party.Â  Moore v. Moore, 300 S.C.
  75, 78, 386 S.E.2d 456, 458 (1989).[8]Â  
 
After the hearing on the second portion of
  the trial regarding whether revocation of the consent was in the best interest
  of the baby, the family court informed the parties on April 21, 2007, that the
  baby should be placed with McCann.Â  In the written order filed May 4, 2007, the
  court noted that McCann:Â  had a suitable home; was well-educated and
  financially stable; had bonded with the child; had strong family support; and
  demonstrated â€œnatural, instinctive and appropriate parenting skills and great
  motivation to being the full-time parent, nurturer, and protector of the
  child.â€Â  The court also noted that both McCann and the Does were â€œpeople of
  character and integrity who are committed to the well-being of this beautiful
  child,â€ and that the Does had demonstrated a great capacity for parenting and
  had a loving, nurturing home.Â  However, the court found that under the facts
  and circumstances of the case, it would be in the best interest of the child to
  be raised by McCann, her biological mother, and it ordered the child to be
  placed with McCann by May 6, 2007.
Both McCann and the Does presented evidence that they
  have sufficient housing, financial resources, extended support systems, and
  child care options.Â  McCann and the Does appear to be fit, they all obviously
  love the baby very much, and, with the exception of the first eleven weeks of
  her life, the baby has spent much time in both households bonding with the
  parties and the extended families.Â  However, in light of the involuntariness of
  McCannâ€™s consent for relinquishment, we agree with the family court that it
  would be in the childâ€™s best interest for the consent to be withdrawn.Â 
  Further, with both sides proving an equal ability to care for the child, we
  agree with the family court that it would be in the childâ€™s best interest for
  custody to be returned to McCann, the biological parent.Â   
CONCLUSION
Adoption is a wonderful institution, bringing together
  parents who want children with children who need loving homes.Â  However,
  protections need to be in place for both biological and adoptive parents to
  ensure the decision to give a child for adoption is a thoughtful and certain
  one and not likely to be challenged in a long, arduous, and
  emotionally-wrenching legal process as has happened in this case.Â   
Nevertheless, we agree with the family court in the
  present case that, looking at the totality of the circumstances, McCann proved
  she was incapable of giving a voluntary consent.Â  It is in the best interest of
  the child for the consent for relinquishment be revoked and the child to be returned
  to McCann.Â   
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., and
  MOORE, J., concur. PLEICONES, J., concurring in result. WALLER, J., dissenting
  in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE
  WALLER:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In
  my opinion, the evidence clearly establishes that the biological mother, Laura
  McCann, voluntarily signed a relinquishment form which complied with the statutory
  requirements set out by the Legislature.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§
  20-7-1700 & -1705 (Supp. 2007).Â  Because the relinquishment form complied
  with the statute, and McCann failed to prove duress or coercion, I would hold
  that the family court erred by revoking McCannâ€™s consent to the adoption.

	â€œRelinquishmentâ€ is defined as:
	[T]he informed and voluntary release in writing of all
  parental rights with respect to a child by a parent to a child placing agency
  or to a person who facilitates the placement of a child for the purpose of
  adoption and to whom the parent has given the right to consent to the adoption
  of the child.

S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1650(h) (Supp. 2007).[9] Â Withdrawal of any consent or relinquishment is permitted only when the
  court finds[10] the withdrawal is in the best interests of the child and the consent or
  relinquishment was given involuntarily or was obtained under duress or through
  coercion.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1720 (Supp. 2007).Â   
The
  majority concludes that the evidence showed McCannâ€™s â€œemotional stressors and
  suffering caused impaired functioning,â€ which in turn rendered her
  relinquishment involuntary.Â  However, an action is involuntary when it is
  performed under duress, force, or coercion,[11] and the crux of this case really is whether McCann acted while under duress.Â 
  As noted by the majority opinion, duress is â€œâ€˜a condition of mind produced by improper external pressure or influence that practically destroys the free agency
  of a party and causes [her] to do an act or form a contract not of [her] own
  volition.â€™â€Â  Phillips v. Baker, 284 S.C. 134, 137, 325 S.E.2d 533,
  535 (1985) (emphasis added, citation omitted).Â   
In
  my opinion, there is no compelling evidence that McCannâ€™s â€œemotional stressorsâ€
  were anything but internal in nature.[12]Â 
  Therefore, although I would agree with the family courtâ€™s conclusion that
  McCann was in an emotional state, the family court erred in finding her consent
  was given involuntarily.Â  Circumstances such as temporary depression or
  emotional distress simply are not sufficient, in and of themselves, to
  invalidate a consent to adoption.Â  See, e.g., In re J.N.,
  95 P.3d 414, 419 (Wash. Ct. App. 2004) (â€œemotional stress alone does not
  vitiate an otherwise voluntary decision to relinquish parental rightsâ€), review
    denied, 114 P.3d 1198 (2005); Boatwright v. Walker, 715 S.W.2d 237,
  242-43 (Ky. Ct. App. 1986) (consent to adoption will not be revoked based
  upon emotional distress or temporary depression; a showing of fraud or duress
  is required); Regenold v. Baby Fold, Inc., 355 N.E.2d 361,
  363-65 (Ill. App. Ct. 1976) (where the 19-year-oldÂ  biological mother was
  experiencing â€œa great deal of stress,â€ the court nonetheless reversed the lower
  courtâ€™s finding of duress because there was no evidence that her consent to
  adoption was the product of â€œthird party persuasion, inducement, deception, or
  dominationâ€), affâ€™d 369 N.E.2d 858 (1977).
Moreover,
  to suggest that because others offered support to McCann regarding her adoption
  decision, this encouragement somehow acted to coerce McCann into signing the
  relinquishment is a sad commentary, indeed.Â  Support for a parentâ€™s choice to
  place a baby for adoption is something that should be promoted, although
  clearly the decision should never be forced upon a parent.[13]
Furthermore,
  there is significant evidence which clearly refutes the idea that McCann was in
  any way coerced to give up her baby for adoption.Â  For example, McCann herself:Â 
  (1) initially raised the issue of adoption to her nurses and postpartum
  obstetrician; (2) requested information about adoption agencies from the social
  worker; (3) called the private adoption agency and arranged a meeting with
  Helen Duschinski for the next day at the hospital; and (4) called Duschinski
  when she was late arriving and gave her directions to the hospital.
Duschinski
  eventually arrived with the Doesâ€™ attorney, Rick Corley, and another
  attorney, Hector Esquivel.Â 
  However, only Esquivel and the social worker remained in the hospital room with
  McCann while Esquivel went over all the forms in detail.Â  McCann thereafter
  signed various documents.Â   
Of most importance to the instant case is the
  relinquishment form, which was entitled â€œCONSENT TO ADOPTION.â€Â  As previously
  mentioned, and as conceded by the majority, this form complied with the
  statutory requirements.[14]Â  See Â§Â§ 20-7-1700 & -1705.Â  The purpose of these statutes is â€œto ensure
  that birth parents freely and voluntarily consent to relinquish their
  particular child, and do not do so under conditions of duress.â€Â  Doe v.
    Clark, 318 S.C. 274, 277, 457 S.E.2d 336, 338 (1995) (Waller, J.,
  dissenting).Â   
The main
  reason this particular form is so crucial is because, under South Carolina law,
  there simply is no waiting period before a relinquishment of parental rights
  becomes effective.Â  It is the Legislature, not this Court, that has made this
  pronouncement. Â â€œâ€˜The legal rules on the
  timing of consents are ultimately a compromise between the interest in
  protecting biological mothers from making hasty or ill-informed decisions at a
  time of great physical and emotional stress, and the interest in expediting the
  adoption process for newborns.â€™â€Â  Elizabeth J. Samuels, Time To Decide? The Laws Governing
    Mothersâ€™ Consents To The Adoption Of Their Newborn Infants, 72 Tenn. L. Rev. 509, 541 (2005) (citation omitted).
The
  Legislature has chosen to safeguard this difficult decision-making process with
  certain requirements regarding both the â€œform and contentâ€ of a consent or
  relinquishment form and the process employed at the actual signing of the
  form.Â  See Â§Â§ 20-7-1700 & -1705.Â  There are numerous other states
  that, unlike South Carolina, provide for various waiting and/or revocation periods.[15]Â 
  Nonetheless, this Court simply is not empowered â€œto effect
  a change in the statutes enacted by the Legislature.â€Â  State v. Corey D.,
  339 S.C. 107, 120, 529 S.E.2d 20, 27 (2000).Â   
In
  other words, although it might seem unwise that under South Carolina law a
  biological parent does not have even a few days to retract such an important
  decision as relinquishing oneâ€™s rights to her own child, this Court may not â€œsecond guess the
  wisdom or folly of decisions of the Legislature.â€Â  Id. at 121, 529
  S.E.2d 20, 27 (citing Keyserling v. Beasley, 322 S.C. 83, 86, 470 S.E.2d
  100, 101 (1996)).
The
  Legislature has set the parameters for adoption.Â  Thus, in order to have her
  consent to adoption withdrawn, McCann was required to prove her â€œrelinquishment
  was given involuntarily or was obtained under duress or through coercion.â€Â  Â§ 20-7-1720.
  Â Because it is my opinion McCann did not make such a showing, I would reverse
  the family courtâ€™s order revoking McCannâ€™s consent to the adoption.

[1] Although Dr. Gormanâ€™s notes reflect McCann was
  â€œconsidering adoption,â€ Dr. Gorman testified McCann personally told her she had
  decided on adoption because she did not feel at that point in her life that she
  could handle a baby and McCann seemed at peace with that decision.  
[2]Â 
  There is some debate over Hewesâ€™ status as either an intern or unlicensed
  masters social work student.Â  For purposes of this opinion, we merely refer to
  Hewes as a social worker.  
[3]Â  The Does raise sixteen sub-issues pointing out facts
  they allege show McCann failed to meet her burden regarding the involuntary
  nature of her consent or showing the facts found in the family courtâ€™s order
  were not supported by the record.Â  However, each of these issues goes toward
  the main question regarding voluntariness.
[4]Â 
  There are certain statutory requirements for a
  consent form.Â  For example, a consent or relinquishment form for the purposes
  of adoption must specify:Â  (1) that the consent acts to forfeit all rights and
  obligations of the parent to the child; (2) that the consent â€œmust not be
  withdrawn except by order of the court upon a finding that it is in the best
  interests of the child;â€ and (3) that the consent was not voluntary or was
  obtained through duress or coercion.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1700(A)(6), (7)
  (Supp. 2007).Â  The consent must be signed in the presence of two witnesses, one
  of which must be either a family court judge, an attorney who does not
  represent the prospective adoptive parents, or a person certified to obtain
  consents through the Department of Social Services. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-7-1705(A)(1) - (3) (Supp. 2007).Â  Each witness must certify that the
  provisions of the document were discussed with the person giving consent and
  that the witness believes that the consent was given voluntarily and was not
  obtained by coercion or duress.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1705(B) (Supp. 2007).Â 
  Our review of the consent form in the present case shows it met the technical
  requirements of the statute.Â   
[5]Â 
  As will be discussed further, we are in no way implying by this commentary that
  McCann merely changed her mind in the present case.  
[6]Â 
  Although there is no law allowing a waiting period for a parent to consider the
  enormous decision to give a child up for adoption, it is interesting that the
  law provides for waiting periods in consumer transactions.Â  See, e.g.,
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 37-2-502 (2002) (providing that consumers have three days to
  change their mind about a home solicitation sale).Â  However, the Legislature
  enacted a waiting period of sorts for biological parents who wish to use the
  Department of Social Services for adoption placement.Â  See S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-2323 (Supp. 2007) (â€œThe Department of Social Services, before it
  may accept as a client a parent or parents, or prospective parent or parents
  who wish to relinquish their child for adoption, must first provide them with
  an informational brochure which outlines the services available from and the
  procedure used to select adoptive parents by the Department and by the licensed
  private adoption agencies in this State . . . The Department may not accept the
  above persons as clients until a period of forty-eight hours has elapsed from
  the time they are furnished this brochure . . . .â€).Â  Despite giving parents
  time to consider whether they wish to use a State or private agency for
  adoption, there is no similar provision giving parents time to reflect on the
  more important decision of relinquishment.Â   
[7]Â 
  As with the consent form, we do not find anything particularly misleading about
  the counseling or medical power of attorney forms.Â  However, because McCann had
  impaired functioning in the present case, we give great deference to the family
  courtâ€™s determination that McCannâ€™s testimony in this regard was credible.Â Â  
 
[8]Â 
  The Does complain the family court erred in using the best interest analysis
  applied in custody situations, including the preference for the biological
  parent, because the revocation statute does not indicate a preference for the
  biological parent over the adoptive parent.Â  The statute does not indicate the
  best interest analysis to be employed is any different from that used in any
  other case concerning the welfare of children.Â  While we understand the Doesâ€™
  concern that the presumption in favor of biological parents would devastate any
  chance an adoptive parent had of enforcing the relinquishment in the face of a
  challenge, we note the statute requires the biological parent to prove both:Â 
  (1) the consent was involuntary; and (2) withdrawal was in the best
  interest of the child.Â  Aside from the situation before us, the burden of
  proving the involuntariness of the consent for relinquishment is generally
  difficult.Â  Because a challenge to the consent for relinquishment may only
  occur prior to an adoption, the dispute concerns a custody determination and
  the normal best interest analysis in custody disputes should be employed.
[9] I focus on the term â€œrelinquishmentâ€ because this is
  â€œcommonly used to refer to a motherâ€™s surrender of parental rights to an
  adoption agency that will place the child with adoptive parents.â€ Â Elizabeth J. Samuels, Time To Decide? The Laws Governing
    Mothers' Consents To The Adoption Of Their Newborn Infants, 72 Tenn. L. Rev. 509, 511 n.5 (2005).
[10] On appeal from the family court, this Court may find
  facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  E.g., Phillips v. Baker, 284 S.C. 134, 325 S.E.2d 533 (1985).
[11] Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 574 (6th ed.
  1991).
[12] I certainly do not contend that any emotions McCann
  felt were not real, were in any way insignificant, or were her fault.Â  I focus
  instead on the fact that these emotional pressures clearly were not generated or
  caused by the people around her, and therefore do not meet the pressures
  required by the legal definition of duress.
[13] See In re Commâ€™r of Soc. Servs., Suffolk County, 529 N.Y.S.2d 883 (N.Y. App. Div. 1988).Â  In this New York case, the
  appellate court appropriately rejected the birth motherâ€™s claim that her
  consent to adoption had been coerced even though the pregnancy was the result
  of a rape.Â  Notably, the court found that her husbandâ€™s encouragement â€œdid not
  render the circumstances coercive nor did his entreaties impair her ability to
  exercise her free will.â€Â  Id. at 884; see also Anonymous
    v. Anonymous, 530 P.2d 896, 898-99 (Ariz. Ct. App. 1975) (although
  birth motherâ€™s church official advised her in the hospital to â€œrelease the baby
  for adoption,â€ this did not constitute duress).
[14] In addition, although not specifically required by
  statute, the form expressly stated the following:Â  â€œI understand that there is
  no revocation period during which I may withdraw this consent, and that the
  consent is effective immediately upon my signing the consent.â€
[15] An interesting example is Vermont where a biological
  parent may not even execute a relinquishment until at least 36 hours after the baby
  is born and then may revoke the relinquishment within 21 days after the
  relinquishment was executed.Â  See Vt. Stat. Ann. Â§ 2-404(a) (2002); see generally, Cynthia Ellen Szejner, Note, Intercountry Adoptions:Â  Are The Biological
    Parentsâ€™ Rights Protected?, 5 Wash.
  U. Global Stud. L. Rev. 211, 214 & n.24 (2006) (where the author notes
  the â€œlength of time that adoption statutes allow for a birth parent to revoke
  consent to the adoption varies among the Statesâ€ and also cites 39 different
  state statutes, most of which have a time period during which consent may be
  revoked without a showing of fraud or duress).

description: The Supreme Court has amended Rule 30 of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement (RLDE) to add a provision dealing with a suspended or disbarred lawyerâ€™s failure to timely surrender his or her certificate to practice law or to timely file the affidavit required by Rule 30. The Supreme Court of South Carolina



The Supreme Court of South Carolina
RE:  Amendment to Rule 30 of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement

ORDER

Pursuant to Article V, §4 of the South Carolina Constitution, the Rule 30 of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement (RLDE) contained in Rule 413, SCACR, is amended to add the following:

   (h)  Failure to Comply.  A disbarred or suspended lawyer who fails to comply with the requirements of this rule may be held in criminal or civil contempt by the Supreme Court.  Further, if a disbarred or suspended lawyer fails to timely surrender the certificate to practice law or to timely file the affidavit as required by sections (f) and (g) of this rule, the time before the disbarred or suspended lawyer is eligible to seek reinstatement under Rules 32 or 33, RLDE, shall not begin to run until the certificate and affidavit are actually received by the Clerk of the Supreme Court.

This amendment shall be effective immediately.  It shall apply to lawyers who are disbarred or suspended on or after the date of this order.
 Further, for lawyers who are disbarred or suspended before the date of this order and have not surrendered their certificate to practice law or filed the affidavit, they must surrender the certificate and/or file the affidavit within thirty (30) days of the date of this order.  If they fail to do so, the time before they are eligible to seek reinstatement under Rules 32 or 33, RLDE, shall be tolled and shall not begin to run again until their certificate and/or affidavit are actually received by the Clerk of this Court.
 IT IS SO ORDERED.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina

ORDER

The Office of  Disciplinary Counsel has filed a petition asking this Court to place respondent  on interim suspension pursuant to Rule 17(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, and  seeking the appointment of an attorney to protect respondent’s clients’  interests pursuant to Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.  Respondent consents to the suspension.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Clarence D.
      Speaks, Jr., Respondent,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Greenville County
John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge
Â Edward W. Miller, Post Conviction Relief
  Judge
Opinion No. 26469
Submitted February 21, 2008 - Filed April
  14, 2008Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Karen C.
  Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Deputy
  Chief Attorney Wanda H. Carter, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent
  Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In this case, the post-conviction relief (PCR) court found trial
  counsel ineffective for failing to request an identification instruction at
  trial, and therefore, granted Respondent Clarence Speaks relief.Â  This Court
  granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari, and we reverse the PCR
  courtâ€™s decision.


Factual/Procedural Background
A grand jury indicted Respondent for assault and
  battery with intent to kill (ABWIK) and first-degree burglary following an
  incident where four people allegedly entered Belinda Sullivanâ€™s apartment and
  assaulted her boyfriend, Patrick Brock.Â  At trial, Belinda testified that
  around 2:30 a.m., she heard a knock and cracked open the door to see Mark Jefferies,
  her ex-boyfriend, along with Respondent, Respondentâ€™s mother, Bonnie, and
  Respondentâ€™s sister, Angel.Â  Belinda testified that Respondent, Bonnie, and
  Angel were Markâ€™s cousins and that she knew them through her previous
  relationship with Mark.Â  Belinda testified that all four individuals forced
  their way into her apartment, asked her why she let Patrick attack Mark,[1] and then proceeded upstairs to the bedroom where Patrick was sleeping.Â  Belinda
  testified that once in the bedroom, Respondent began striking Patrick and
  eventually threw a television on Patrick.Â  Patrick provided essentially the
  same testimony and identified Respondent as the person who assaulted him.Â  
Respondent
  presented several witnesses to rebut Belindaâ€™s and Patrickâ€™s testimonies.Â  Specifically,
  Respondentâ€™s girlfriend testified that Respondent was with her on the night of
  the incident, but that Respondent left her house for thirty minutes with his
  father.Â  Respondentâ€™s father testified that although he and Respondent drove to
  Belindaâ€™s apartment, they arrived after the altercation had taken place.Â 
  Angel, Bonnie, and Mark all admitted that they were present during the
  altercation, but testified that Mark assaulted Patrick and specifically
  testified that Respondent was never there.Â  Finally, Respondent testified that he
  was not at Belindaâ€™s apartment during the altercation and that he did not
  assault Patrick.Â  The jury found Respondent guilty of ABWIK and burglary.Â  
At
  the PCR hearing, Respondent argued that trial counsel should have investigated
  Patrickâ€™s inability to identify him as the assailant.Â  Respondent testified
  that Patrick mistook Respondent for two different people at his bond hearing,
  and that on a later occasion, he saw Patrick at the probation office but that
  Patrick did not recognize him.Â  Additionally, Respondent alleged that the
  arrest warrant described the assailant as five feet, six inches and 155 pounds
  but that he is six feet and 200 pounds.Â  Respondent alleged that Mark more
  accurately matched the description in the warrant.Â  Trial counsel testified
  that Respondent never informed him that Patrick failed to recognize him at the
  bond hearing and that he raised identification issues at trial.Â  
The
  PCR court found that the identification of Respondent as the assailant was an
  â€œintegral issueâ€ at trial.Â  Additionally, the PCR court found numerous factors
  indicated that the identification of Respondent as the assailant was peculiarly
  suspect.Â  Specifically, these factors included testimony that Respondent was
  not involved in the assault, the description of the assailant in the arrest
  warrant, Respondentâ€™s testimony regarding Patrickâ€™s failure to recognize him,
  and the likely possibility that Belinda implicated Respondent instead of Mark
  out of fear of Patrickâ€™s retaliation against Mark.Â  Accordingly, the PCR court
  held that trial counsel was ineffective for failing to request a jury
  instruction on identification
This
  Court granted certiorari to review the PCR courtâ€™s decision, and the State
  presents the following issue for review:

	Did the
  PCR court err in finding trial counsel ineffective for failing to request an
  identification instruction?


Standard of Review
In
  post-conviction proceedings, the burden of proof is on the applicant to prove
  the allegations in his application.Â  Butler v. State, 286
  S.C. 441, 442, 334 S.E.2d 813, 814 (1985).Â  On appeal, the PCR courtâ€™s
  ruling should be upheld if it is supported by any evidence of probative value
  in the record.Â  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119,
  386 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1989).
Law/Analysis
The State argues
  that the PCR court erred in finding trial counsel ineffective for failing to
  request an identification jury charge.Â  We agree.Â  
In
  order to establish a claim for ineffective assistance of counsel, the applicant
  must show that: (1) counsel
  failed to render reasonably effective assistance under prevailing professional
  norms, and (2) counselâ€™s deficient performance prejudiced the applicantâ€™s case. Â Strickland
    v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 687 (1984).Â  
In United States v. Telfaire, the court recommended â€œthat trial courts include, as a
  matter of routine, an identification instructionâ€ and provided a model
  identification instruction.Â  Id. 469 F.2d 552, 555 n.11 (D.C. Cir. 1972).Â 
  The model instruction, which emphasized that the State had to prove the
  accuracy of the identification of the defendant beyond a reasonable doubt, â€œwas
  designed to focus the attention of the jury on the identification issue and
  minimize the risk of conviction through false or mistaken identification.â€Â  State v. Jones, 344
  S.C. 48, 59, 543 S.E.2d 541, 547 (2001).Â  In State v. Simmons, this Court â€œadmonish[ed] the trial bench that in single witness
  identification cases the court should instruct the jury that the burden of
  proving the identity of the defendant rests with the state.â€Â  308
  S.C. 80, 83, 417 S.E.2d 92, 94 (1992).
In
  our opinion, there is no evidence to support the PCR courtâ€™s finding that trial
  counsel was ineffective for failing to request an identification instruction.Â 
  Specifically, we do not believe that identification was an â€œintegral issueâ€ at
  Respondentâ€™s trial.Â  Belinda and Patrick testified that Respondent, Mark,
  Angel, and Bonnie entered the apartment and that Respondent assaulted Patrick.Â 
  On the other hand, Respondentâ€™s witnesses testified that only Mark, Angel, and
  Bonnie entered the apartment, that Mark assaulted Patrick, and that Respondent
  was never present during the altercation.Â  Thus,
  the jury was not faced with the issue of whether Belinda and Patrick
  misidentified Respondent, but rather whether to believe their testimonies or instead
  whether to believe the defenseâ€™s witnessesâ€™ testimonies.[2] Â Accordingly, we believe that the critical issue at trial was witness
  credibility, an issue on which the trial court sufficiently charged the jury.Â  This
  conclusion is further supported by the PCR courtâ€™s specific findings. Â For
  example, the PCR court noted that Respondentâ€™s witnesses testified that
  Respondent was not present during the assault and the PCR court determined that
  Belinda had motivation to falsely implicate Respondent.Â  
Additionally, we
  believe cases in which an identification charge was relevant are readily distinguishable from this case.Â  For example, Simmons involved a police officer identifying the defendant following an undercover
  operation, and in Jones and State
    v. Patterson, 337
  S.C. 215, 522 S.E.2d 845 (Ct. App. 1999), neither
  victim/eyewitness identifying the defendant knew the defendant prior to the
  crime.Â  Conversely, in the instant case, the State provided two
  eyewitnesses who unequivocally identified Respondent as the assailant.Â Â  See Jones, 344 S.C. at 59, 543 S.E.2d at 547 (holding a Telfaire charge was unnecessary where the case did not involve
  a single witness identification and where, given the witnessesâ€™ degree of
  certainty, there appeared very little likelihood of mistaken identification) and State v. Motes, 264 S.C. 317, 326, 215 S.E.2d 190, 194 (1975)
  (finding no error in failing to give a Telfaire instruction where
  identification â€œpresented no peculiar problemâ€).Â  
Accordingly,
  we hold that there is no evidence to support the PCR courtâ€™s decision that
  trial counsel was ineffective for failing to request an identification
  instruction.Â  

Conclusion
For the
  foregoing reasons, we reverse the PCR courtâ€™s order granting Respondent
  relief.Â  
MOORE, WALLER, BEATTY, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J.,
  dissenting in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my opinion, since there
  is evidence of probative value in the record to support the post-conviction
  relief (PCR) judgeâ€™s finding of ineffective assistance of counsel, we should
  uphold his decision.Â  E.g., Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 386
  S.E.2d 624 (1989).
The majority finds
  error in the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that identification was the â€œintegral issueâ€
  at Respondentâ€™s trial, stating that instead the â€œcritical issueâ€ was witness
  credibility.Â  I do not understand this distinction, as the question was whether
  the witnessesâ€™ identification of Respondent as a participant in the crimes was credible.Â 
  Moreover, the fact that two Stateâ€™s witnesses unequivocally identified
  Respondent as the assailant does not negate the importance of identification in
  the case, but merely highlights the centrality of the issue given that four
  defense witnesses, including those who admitted being present at the scene, as
  well as Respondent testified that he was not involved.Â  
I would uphold the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that trial counsel was ineffective in failing to request a
  jury charge emphasizing the Stateâ€™s burden to establish the accuracy of
  Respondentâ€™s identification beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Cherry v. State, supra.


[1] Earlier that evening, Mark and Patrick got into a physical altercation in which
  apparently Patrick injured Mark. 
[2] This, in our view, is the distinction between the issue of identification and
  witness credibility.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Michael R. Batchelor, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Aiken County
Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26455
Heard January 22, 2008 - Refiled April 21, 2008Ã‚Â Ã‚Â Ã‚Â  
AFFIRMED 


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M.
  Dudek, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for
  appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney Salley W. Elliott, and
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., of Columbia; and
  Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE MOORE: Ã‚Â Appellant Michael Batchelor was convicted of several
  charges stemming from an automobile collision in which his three minor sons
  were killed and three other minors were injured.Ã‚Â  The charges include two
  counts of felony driving under the influence (felony DUI) causing death, two
  counts of felony DUI causing great bodily injury, and one count of involuntary
  manslaughter.[1]Ã‚Â 
  After we issued our original opinion affirming appellantÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s convictions,[2] appellant petitioned for rehearing.Ã‚Â  We deny the petition for rehearing, withdraw
  our original opinion in this matter, and substitute it with this opinion
  affirming the trial courtÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s decision.
FACTS
The facts are undisputed.Ã‚Â  AppellantÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s three
  sonsÃ¢â‚¬â€Raymond Groomes (referred to as Ã¢â‚¬Å“AshtonÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½), and Brandon and Drew
  BatchelorÃ¢â‚¬â€lived with their mother.Ã‚Â  On July 11, 2002, they were invited along
  with three friends to appellantÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s house where appellant supplied them with
  alcohol.Ã‚Â  All of the boys were between the ages of thirteen and fifteen. 
At some point in the afternoon, appellant and the
  boys left the house in appellantÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s pick-up truck to buy more alcohol and look
  for some marijuana.Ã‚Â  Appellant was driving.Ã‚Â  After veering off the side of the
  road, appellant decided he was too drunk to drive and he wanted Ashton to
  drive.Ã‚Â  Ashton, who was fifteen, did not have a driverÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s license or learnerÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s
  permit and AshtonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s friends had never seen him drive a vehicle.Ã‚Â  At appellantÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s
  insistence, Ashton took the wheel.Ã‚Â  Shortly thereafter, Ashton swerved off the
  side of the road and over-corrected, causing the truck to swerve into the
  oncoming lane and collide head-on with another vehicle.Ã‚Â  Both vehicles flipped
  and the truck landed upside-down with Ashton under it.
Ashton was dead at the scene.Ã‚Â  A
  toxicology report indicated AshtonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s blood alcohol was .108 at the time of his
  death.Ã‚Â  Brandon and Drew died later at the hospital.Ã‚Â  The other boys and
  appellant were injured.[3]Ã‚Â 
  At the hospital, appellant told the investigating officers that Ashton was
  driving and that he had given the boys alcohol.Ã‚Â  Appellant himself smelled
  strongly of alcohol.Ã‚Â  
The State proceeded to trial on a theory of
  accomplice liability.Ã‚Â  It was undisputed that appellant was not driving at the
  time of the wreck.Ã‚Â  After he was found guilty, appellant expressed remorse that
  he had caused the death of his three children and serious injury to the other
  boys.Ã‚Â  
ISSUES

	1.  Should the
  indictments for felony DUI have been quashed?
	2.  Should a
  directed verdict have been granted?

DISCUSSION
1.Ã‚Â  Indictments
Appellant claims the four
  indictments for felony DUI should have been quashed.Ã‚Â  He contends that because the
  indictments charged him as a principal rather than as an accomplice, the grand
  jury was misled regarding the facts of the case.Ã‚Â  
The regularity of grand jury proceedings is
  presumed absent clear evidence to the contrary; the burden is on the defendant
  to prove facts upon which a challenge to the legality of the grand jury
  proceedings is predicated.Ã‚Â  Evans v. State, 363 S.C. 495, 611 S.E.2d 510
  (2005); State v. Griffin, 277 S.C. 193, 285 S.E.2d 631 (1981).Ã‚Â  
Here, the fact that the indictments
  presented to the grand jury charged appellant as a principal for felony DUI
  does not prove the State misinformed the grand jury that appellant was the
  driver at the time of the wreck.Ã‚Â  It is well-settled that an indictment
  charging the defendant as a principal will support a conviction based on
  accomplice liability.Ã‚Â  State v. Dickman, 341 S.C. 293, 534 S.E.2d 268
  (2000); State v. Leonard, 292 S.C. 133, 355 S.E.2d 270 (1987);Ã‚Â  State
    v. Cox, 258 S.C. 114, 187 S.E.2d 525 (1972);Ã‚Â  State v. Hicks, 257
  S.C. 279, 185 S.E.2d 746 (1971); State v. Hunter, 79 S.C. 73, 60 S.E.
  240 (1908).Ã‚Â  Accordingly, the State may present an indictment charging a
  defendant as a principal based on information of aiding and abetting the crime
  charged.Ã‚Â  There is no evidence the grand jury process was compromised in any
  way.Ã‚Â  We find no error.
2.Ã‚Â  Directed
  verdict
AppellantÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s motion for directed
  verdicts on the four felony DUI charges was denied.Ã‚Â  Appellant contends this
  was error because the indictments charged him as a principal and there is no
  evidence he was the driver, resulting in a material variance in proof.Ã‚Â  See State v. Evans, 322 S.C. 78, 470 S.E.2d 97 (1996) (material
  variance between the charge and the proof entitles the defendant to a directed
  verdict).Ã‚Â  
Felony DUI is subject to accomplice
  liability based on a factual scenario that includes evidence of aiding and
  abetting as in this case.Ã‚Â  As noted above, an accomplice may be indicted as a
  principal.Ã‚Â  There is no material variance in proof when the indictment charges
  the defendant as a principal and the evidence at trial proves he was guilty as
  an accomplice.Ã‚Â  AppellantÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s motion for directed verdicts was properly denied.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ.,
  concur.


[1] Appellant was sentenced to concurrent terms of
  twenty-five years and fined $25,100 for each felony DUI causing death, and two
  concurrent terms of fifteen years and a fine of $10,100 for felony DUI causing
  great bodily injury, these to run consecutive to the twenty-five-year terms.Ã‚Â 
  He was also convicted of three counts of unlawful conduct towards a child and
  given three ten-year terms and three $10,000 fines, and two counts of
  contributing to the delinquency of a minor for which he received two three-year
  terms and three $3,000 fines, all concurrent.
[2] State v. Batchelor, Op. No. 26455 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed March 10, 2008). 
[3] The driver of the other car escaped with only minor
  injuries.

description: This is a direct appeal from a masterâ€™s award in a claim brought on a title insurance policy.
