THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Charles
      Salmonsen, individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated, Appellants-Respondents,
				v.
				CGD, Inc.,
      f/k/a Charleston Gypsum Dealers & Supply Co., Inc., Frank Crider, Raymond
      G. Wolford, Henry (Hank) Futch, and Harold (Hal) Futch, Respondents-Appellants,
				
				v.
				Parex, Inc., Respondent-Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge 
Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26475
Heard October 17, 2007 - Filed April 28,
  2008Â Â  
DISMISSED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
  REMANDED


	
		
			
				Mary L.
  Arnold and Justin Oâ€™Toole Lucey, both of Mount Pleasant, for Appellants-Respondents.
				Joseph
  E. DaPore, Stephen L. Brown, Russell G. Hines, all of Young, Clement, Rivers, of
  Charleston; Robert T. Lyles, Jr., of Lyles & Lyles, of Charleston; R.
  Hawthorne Barrett, Steven W. Ouzts, John E. Cuttino, all of Turner, Padget,
  Graham & Laney, of Columbia; Steve L. Smith, of Smith, Collins, Newton
  & Koontz, of Charleston, for Respondents-Appellants.
			
		
	


JUSTICE BEATTY: Â This is
  a direct appeal of a class action suit involving damages arising out of the
  application of allegedly defective synthetic stucco (Exterior Insulation and Finish
  System, â€œEIFSâ€) to Charles Salmonsenâ€™s residential home and those homeowners similarly
  situated in the Charleston area. Â The Court granted Salmonsenâ€™s motion for the
  appeal to be certified from the Court of Appeals to this Court. Â The appeal and
  cross-appeals raise multiple substantive and procedural issues regarding the
  certification of the class.Â  We dismiss in part, reverse in part, and remand.
Factual/Procedural History
On October 19, 2000, Salmonsen filed his original
  Complaint against Parex, Inc. (the stucco manufacturer), Jeff Thomas d/b/a
  Thomas Construction (the general contractor for the residence), Mike Tenny
  d/b/a Synco Enterprise (the subcontractor responsible for applying EIFS), and Charleston
  Gypsum n/k/a CSR America (the distributor). Â In his Complaint, Salmonsen
  claimed his residential home sustained water intrusion damage resulting from
  allegedly defective construction materials, particularly the Exterior Insulation
  and Finish System (â€œEIFSâ€).Â  Based on these damages, Salmonsen asserted causes
  of action for breach of implied warranty, breach of express warranty,
  negligence, and strict liability.Â  Prior to the scheduled trial date of October
  14, 2002, Salmonsen settled and entered into a release with the defendants.Â  In
  the settlement documents, Salmonsen specifically reserved his claims against
  CGD, Inc., f/k/a Charleston Gypsum Dealers & Supply Co., Inc.[1]
On October 23,
  2002, Salmonsen filed an Amended Complaint on behalf of himself and other
  similarly situated homeowners, which named CGD, Inc., f/k/a Charleston Gypsum
  Dealers & Supply Co., Inc. (â€œCGDâ€), and each of its former shareholders as
  defendants. Â In the Amended Complaint, Salmonsen alleged products liability
  claims against CGD for breach of implied warranty, negligence, and strict
  liability.Â  As to the former shareholders, Salmonsen alleged they were
  personally liable for misconduct associated with the distribution of the
  corporationâ€™s assets.Â  
On February 18,
  2003, Salmonsen moved for class certification.Â  In response, CGD filed a
  memorandum in opposition and a motion to amend its Answer to include third-party
  defendants who had contributed to the alleged damages of the class of
  homeowners.Â  After a hearing, Circuit Court Judge Markley Dennis, Jr., issued
  an order on September 25, 2003, in which he granted Salmonsenâ€™s motion to
  certify the class and denied CGDâ€™s motion.Â  In his order, Judge Dennis found
  that all of the prerequisites for class certification were satisfied pursuant
  to Rule 23(a) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure. Â In addition to
  these criteria, Judge Dennis also based his decision to certify the class on
  the ground that there was a limited fund to satisfy the class claims given the
  corporation was dissolved and had only a limited amount of insurance coverage
  available.Â  Judge Dennis certified the following class:Â  

	All
  persons and entities that own or have owned structures clad with Parex EIFS
  sold by the Defendant between January 1, 1991 and May 15, 1995.Â  This class
  excludes:
	
		
			a) 
			Employees of the Defendant; and
 
		
		
			b)
			Those persons who have released the Defendant or 
			are currently in litigation with the Defendant.  
		
	

Subsequently,
  CGD and the shareholders jointly filed two motions requesting Judge Dennis to
  reconsider his orders certifying the class and denying the addition of
  third-party defendants.Â  By orders dated December 15, 2003, Judge Dennis
  amended the prior order by ruling that the class would be conditionally
  certified and permitting CGD additional time to conduct class discovery.Â  Judge
  Dennis also granted CGD leave to amend its Answer to list Parex as a
  third-party defendant.Â  Pursuant to this ruling, the defendants filed an
  Amended Answer and a Third-Party Complaint in which they asserted causes of
  action for indemnity, negligence, negligent misrepresentation, and breach of
  implied warranties.
On
  March 22, 2004, Judge Dennis signed a consent scheduling order in which he
  granted the defendants until May 1, 2004, to file motions to decertify the
  class.Â  Additionally, he ordered the parties to:Â  (1) complete discovery on or
  before July 20, 2004; (2) file all motions by August 20, 2004; and (3) complete
  mediation on or before August 20, 2004.Â  Judge Dennis also informed the parties
  that the case was subject to being called for trial on or after September 20,
  2004. 
After
  conducting discovery, CGD filed a motion on April 30, 2004, to decertify the
  conditionally-certified class.Â  In its motion and accompanying memorandum, CGD
  contended that the requirements of Rule 23, SCRCP, were not met and
  certification was inappropriate because trying the case would involve numerous
  separate â€œmini-trials.â€ Â CGD reasoned that the homeowners were distinct in
  their claims and, particularly, their damages.
On October 12,
  2004, Judge Dennis held a hearing on the motion to decertify the class. Â Judge
  Dennis issued a form order in which he denied the motion and indicated that a
  formal order would be forthcoming.Â  Prior to the issuance of the formal order, CGD and Parex filed motions to bifurcate the claims of individual class members
  and, in the alternative, requested a litigation plan for the class action.Â  On
  January 14, 2005, Circuit Court Judge Roger Young, the Chief Administrative
  Judge, held a pre-trial conference on these motions.Â Â  Judge Young removed the
  case from the trial roster, requested the parties submit proposed trial plans,
  and assigned the case to himself for all further proceedings.
On
  February 24, 2005, Judge Dennis issued a formal order explaining his denial of
  the defendantsâ€™ motion for decertification.Â  In his order, Judge Dennis
  reiterated that all of the criteria of Rule 23(a), SCRCP, were met to warrant
  certification of the class.Â  He also emphasized that â€œthe differences in the
  claims and damages of these homeowners are not so great that they would weigh
  against class certification.â€ Â Additionally, Judge Dennis recognized that â€œthe
  court faces a continuing duty to ensure that the requirements of Rule 23 remain
  satisfied.Â  The decision to certify a class is not set in stone; the trial
  court retains the power to decertify or modify the class at any time prior to
  final judgment.â€
On
  February 25, 2005, Judge Young held a second pre-trial hearing to consider the
  partiesâ€™ proposed trial plans and to address the issue of class notification.Â 
  By order dated May 31, 2005, Judge Young established an â€œopt-inâ€ notification
  procedure. Â In reaching this conclusion, Judge Young found the â€œopt-inâ€
  procedure was â€œthe preferred method of litigating the instant case by serving
  the interests of the parties and furthering judicial economy.â€Â  Judge Young
  further explained that â€œan opt-in provision is the most pragmatic procedure to
  facilitate the management of this case.Â  The makeup of this Class should only
  contain, at most, a narrow group of members, namely the homeowners as
  identified by sales invoices provided by Defendants.â€Â  Judge Young declined to
  establish a trial management plan until after the class had been closed and the
  class members had been identified.Â Â Â  Significantly, Judge Young specifically reserved
  the â€œauthority to alter, amend, or modify its orders as changes during the
  course of this case may warrant.â€
All
  parties timely appealed the orders of Judge Dennis and Judge Young.Â  Salmonsen
  appealed Judge Youngâ€™s May 31, 2005 order establishing the â€œopt-inâ€
  notification procedure.Â  CGD cross-appealed, challenging Judge Dennisâ€™s
  February 17, 2005 order and Judge Youngâ€™s May 31, 2005 order denying decertification
  of the class.Â  Parex also cross-appealed challenging Judge Dennisâ€™s three
  orders converting the case into a class action and Judge Youngâ€™s order
  permitting the case to continue as a class action.Â Â Â  
Although
  there are multiple issues raised by the parties, we believe this case
  essentially presents the following questions:Â  (1) whether these appeals are
  interlocutory?; (2) whether Judge Dennis erred in conditionally certifying the
  class?; and (3) whether Judge Young erred in converting the class to an
  â€œopt-inâ€ class?Â  Accordingly, in the interest of clarity and brevity, we have
  consolidated some of the issues raised by the parties.Â  Because the question of
  appealability is a threshold issue in the case, we have chosen to address it
  first.
I. Appealability
The
  substantive differences between the orders at issue necessitates that this
  Court engage in a bifurcated appealability analysis.Â  Specifically, we must
  determine whether the class certification orders are immediately appealable and
  whether the subsequent orders regarding the â€œopt-inâ€ notification procedure are
  immediately appealable.Â  For reasons that will be more fully discussed, we dismiss
  the appeal of the class certification orders and grant the continued review of
the â€œopt-inâ€ orders. 

A.
The
  general rule established by this Court is that class certification orders are
  not immediately appealable. See Eldridge v. City of Greenwood,
  308 S.C. 125, 127, 417 S.E.2d 532, 534 (1992) (â€œOrders under Rule 23, SCRCP are
  interlocutory and thus, immediately appealable only in certain
  circumstances.â€); see also Ferguson v. Charleston Lincoln Mercury,
    Inc., 349 S.C. 558, 565, 564 S.E.2d 94, 98 (2002) (â€œUsually, an order
  denying class certification is interlocutory and not immediately appealable.â€); Schein v. Lamar, 274 S.C. 329, 331, 263 S.E.2d 383, 384 (1980) (finding
  issue of class certification sought to be raised on appeal was interlocutory
  and appeal regarding that issue was dismissed); Knowles v. Standard Sav.
    & Loan Assâ€™n, 274 S.C. 58, 59, 261 S.E.2d 49, 49 (1979) (dismissing
  class certification order as interlocutory on the grounds that â€œ[c]lass
  certification, essentially procedural in nature, does not involve substantial
  or essential legal rights which require attention prior to final judgmentâ€).Â  
This
  Court, however, has reviewed interlocutory orders involving class certification
  when they contain other appealable issues.Â  Ferguson, 349 S.C. at 565,
  564 S.E.2d at 98; see Eldridge, 308 S.C. at 126-28, 417 S.E.2d at
  533-34 (finding order prohibiting a plaintiff from contacting potential members
  of the plaintiff class was in the nature of an injunction and, thus, directly
  appealable).
In its brief, CGD concedes that â€œ[u]nder the present
  law in South Carolina, all appeals in this matter should be dismissed as
  interlocutory.â€Â  Despite this concession, CGD requests to argue against
  precedent and asks this Court accept review of the appeals because the modern
  trend in state and federal jurisdictions is to allow review of class
  certification orders under certain circumstances.Â  CGD believes these appeals
  present the appropriate circumstances for this Court to accept review. Â Â In
  essence, CGD is urging this Court to amend our state rules of civil procedure
  to permit interlocutory review of class certification orders or issue an
  opinion holding these orders fall under the provisions of section 14-3-330(2)
  of the South Carolina Code,[2] which allows appeal from an interlocutory order when the order affects a
  â€œsubstantial rightâ€ and â€œin effect determines the action and prevents judgment
  from which an appeal might be taken or discontinues the action.â€ 
In analyzing this appealability issue, we have, as urged by CGD, reviewed precedent from other state
  and federal jurisdictions.Â  Although the decisions from these jurisdictions are
  instructive, we conclude they are distinguishable and do not warrant a decision
  to review the certification orders in the instant case.
Unlike
  our state appellate courts, the federal courts have been specifically
  authorized by Rule 23(f), which became effective on December 1, 1998,[3] to review class certifications prior to a final judgment.Â  Rule 23(f) provides:

	(f)
  Appeals. A court of appeals may in
  its discretion permit an appeal from an order of a district court granting or
  denying class action certification under this rule if application is made to it
  within ten days after entry of the order. An appeal does not stay proceedings
  in the district court unless the district judge or the court of appeals so
  orders.

Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(f).[4]Â  The Advisory Committee Note to this rule explains:Â  â€œThe court
  of appeals is given unfettered discretion whether to permit the appeal, akin to
  the discretion exercised by the Supreme Court in acting on a petition for
  certiorari . . . Permission to appeal may be granted or denied on the basis of
  any consideration that the court of appeals finds persuasive.â€ However, our
  Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals seems to emphasize that review of interlocutory
  class certification decisions would not be routine.Â  Instead, the Court has noted
  that it would employ a â€œcareful and sparing use of Rule 23(f)â€ to â€œpromote
  judicial economy by enabling the correction of certain manifestly flawed class
  certifications prior to trial and final judgment.â€Â  Lienhart v. Dryvit Sys.
    Inc., 255 F.3d 138, 145 (4th Cir. 2001).Â  Therefore, despite the specific
  authorization, it appears that federal courts, particularly our Fourth Circuit,
  are reticent to grant review of interlocutory class certifications orders.
Similar to the
  federal courts, the state jurisdictions which have granted immediate appeal of
  class certification orders are usually authorized by a state rule of civil
  procedure or a specific statute.Â  See, e.g., Ala. Code Â§ 6-5-642 (2005)
  (Alabama); Ark. R. App. P. Civ. 2(a)(9) (Arkansas); Colo. Rev. Stat. Â§
  13-20-901 (2006)(Colorado); Conn. Gen. Stat. Ann. Â§ 42-110h (2007)
  (Connecticut); Fla. R. App. P. 9.130(a)(3)(vi) (Florida); Ga. Code Ann. Â§ 9-11-23(g)
  (2005)(Georgia); I. C. A. Rule 1.264(3) (Iowa); Kan. Stat. Ann. Â§ 60-223(f)
  (2005) (Kansas); Mo. Rev. Stat. Â§ 512.020(3) (Supp. 2008) (Missouri); N.M.R.A. Rule
  1-023(F) (New Mexico); N.D.R.Civ.P Rule 23(d)(3) (North Dakota); Ohio Rev. Code
  Ann. Â§ 2505.02(B)(5) (2005)(Ohio); Okla. Stat. Ann. tit. 12, Â§ 993(A)(6) (2005)
  (Oklahoma); Or. Rev. Stat. Â§ 19.225 (2003) (Oregon); Tex. Civ. Prac. & Rem.
  Code Â§ 51.014(a)(3) (Supp. 2007) (Texas); see generally Gary D. Spivey,
  Annotation, Appealability of Order Denying Right to Proceed in Form of Class
    Action, 54 A.L.R.3d 595 (1973 & Supp. 2008) (discussing state appellate
  decisions regarding the appealability of orders denying the right to proceed in
  the form of a class action). 
In the absence of
  a rule or statute, several state appellate courts have granted immediate
  review.Â  See, e.g., Indiana Bus. Coll. v. Hollowell, 818 N.E.2d
  943, 945 (Ind. Ct. App. 2004) (granting review of interlocutory appeal of class
  certification decision); Dunn v. State, 635 S.E.2d 604, 606 (N.C. Ct.
  App. 2006)(holding interlocutory appeal of class certification order was
  directly appealable because it involved â€œâ€˜a matter of law or legal inference
  that affect[ed] a substantial right of the appellantâ€™â€(quoting Frost v.
    Mazda Motor of Am., Inc., 540 S.E.2d 324, 327 (N.C. 2000))); Mitchem v.
      Melton, 277 S.E.2d 895, 900-01 (W.Va. 1981) (holding order denying class
  action standing was immediately appealable); but see Gordon v.
    Microsoft Corp., 645 N.W.2d 393, 402-03 (Minn. 2002) (adopting â€œsynthesisâ€
  of federal jurisprudence regarding immediate appeal of class certification
  orders and affirming court of appeals decision denying immediate review of
  class certification order); Basile v. H & R Block, Inc., 926 A.2d
  493, 498 (Pa. Super. Ct. 2007) (holding interlocutory orders granting class
  certification become reviewable on appeal upon the trial courtâ€™s entry of a
  final order).
Although
  the absence of a specific state rule or statute is not dispositive of our
  decision as to the appealability of class certification orders, it presents a
  greater obstacle for this Court to grant review of the appealed orders.[5] Because a decision by this Court to grant immediate appellate
  review of a class certification order would represent a significant departure
  from this stateâ€™s established appealability jurisprudence, we decline to do
  so.Â  We reiterate that the orders do not prevent a judgment from which an
  appeal may be taken nor do they discontinue the action.Â  
B.
We
  reach a different conclusion regarding the appeal of the orders establishing
  the â€œopt-inâ€ notification procedure.Â  Although Salmonsen concedes that an order granting or denying class
  certification is typically treated as an interlocutory appeal by the appellate
  courts of this state, he contends that his appeal from Judge Youngâ€™s order
  establishing the â€œopt-inâ€ notification procedure is properly before this Court
  because it affects a substantial right of class members and the mode of trial.Â 
  Specifically, Salmonsen asserts the ruling of Judge Young â€œis a death knell for
  a number of class membersâ€™ claims because they will no longer be class members
  due to the inhibitions created by changing the matters to an opt-in class.â€[6] Â We agree with Salmonsen that these
  orders affect a mode of trial and, thus, are immediately appealable. Â Moreover,
  this issue presents a novel question of law which should be addressed at this
  time in the interest of judicial economy and guidance to the bench and bar.
â€œPursuant
  to Â§ 14-3-330(2), this Court has held on numerous occasions that when a trial
  courtâ€™s order deprives a party of a mode of trial to which it is entitled to as
  a matter of right, such order is immediately appealable.â€Â  Flagstar Corp. v.
    Royal Surplus Lines, 341 S.C. 68, 72, 533 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2000).Â  â€œThese
  cases not only permit, but indeed require, immediate appeal in the event of the
  denial of a mode of trial to which one is entitled as a matter of right.â€Â  Id.Â  This Courtâ€™s traditional analysis of claims of denial of a mode of trial
  requires a determination of whether or not a party is erroneously denied a
  trial by jury in a law case, or is erroneously required to proceed before a
  jury in an equity case.Â  Id. Â However, the mode of trial analysis
  indubitably includes the consideration of the availability of trial.Â  The
  question of the denial of an actual trial is intrinsic.Â  Here, all parties
  argue that some of the claims of putative class members are barred or would be
  barred by the statute of limitations if the â€œopt-inâ€ procedure is used. 
As
  originally certified by Judge Dennis, the class included â€œAll persons and
  entities that own or have owned structures clad with Parex EIFS sold by the
  Defendant between January 1, 1991 and May 15, 1995.â€Â  By converting this inclusive class to an â€œopt-inâ€ class, Judge
  Youngâ€™s order had the deleterious effect of improperly excluding individuals
  who should be members of the class. Â Although the class has not been
  decertified by the trial judge, the adoption of this notification procedure
  essentially created a class action anomaly. Â See Citgo Ref. & Mktg.,
    Inc. v. Garza, 94 S.W.3d 322, 328 (Tex. App. 2002) (stating â€œan order changing the
      characterization of a class from opt-out to mandatory fundamentally alters the
      nature of the class and therefore is immediately appealableâ€). 
II.
  Â Propriety of â€œOpt-inâ€ Notification
Having
  dismissed the appeal from Judge Dennisâ€™s class certification orders, we confine
  our analysis to a review of Judge Youngâ€™s decision establishing an â€œopt-inâ€
  notice procedure for putative class members.
Salmonsen
  challenges Judge Youngâ€™s ruling on procedural as well as substantive grounds.Â 
  First, Salmonsen contends that Judge Youngâ€™s decision effectively overruled
  Judge Dennisâ€™s prior rulings regarding scheduling of the trial and the class
  certification.Â  Secondly, Salmonsen asserts that an â€œopt-inâ€ notice requirement
  is not recognized in this state and, in the alternative, is not appropriate for
  this class action suit.Â  
Although
  Salmonsen is correct that one circuit court judge may not overrule another, we
  find this rule was not violated in the instant case.Â  See Enoree
    Baptist Church v. Fletcher, 287 S.C. 602, 604, 340 S.E.2d 546, 547 (1986)
  (â€œOne Circuit Court Judge does not have the authority to set aside the order of
  another.â€).
Rules
  23(d)(1) and (2) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure specifically
  permit the trial court to maintain continual control over class action
  proceedings, including the method of class notification.Â  Because Judge Young
  was the Chief Administrative Judge, who was ultimately assigned to the case, he
  was authorized to issue orders governing the trial proceedings which included
  scheduling decisions as well as the method of notification.Â  See Rule
  40(e)(2), SCRCP (permitting scheduling orders to be amended by subsequent Chief
  Administrative Judge).Â  Significantly, Judge Dennis never ruled on the method
  of class notification nor did he designate the action as an â€œopt-outâ€ class
  action. Â Moreover, class certification may be altered at any time prior to a
  decision on the merits.[7]Â  Therefore,
  we find Judge Young properly exercised his discretion and did not overrule any
  prior decisions of Judge Dennis.
As
  to the merits of Salmonsenâ€™s issue, we believe, for reasons that will be more
  fully discussed, that the â€œopt-outâ€ notification procedure is appropriate and
  should be used in this case and future class action suits.
To
  analyze this issue, it is instructive to compare Rule 23(d)(2) of the South
  Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure with its federal counterpart, Rule 23(c)(2).Â 
  In doing so, we are cognizant that our appellate decisions have relied on
  federal precedent with respect to class action cases, but have also noted the
  significant differences between the two rules.Â  See Littlefield v. South
    Carolina Forestry Commâ€™n, 337 S.C. 348, 354, 523 S.E.2d 781, 784 (1999)
  (â€œOur state class action rule differs significantly from its federal
  counterpart.Â  The drafters of Rule 23, South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure
  (SCRCP) intentionally omitted from our state rule the additional requirements
  found in Federal Rule 23(B), Federal Rules of Civil Procedure (FRCP).Â  By
  omitting the additional requirements, Rule 23, SCRCP, endorses a more expansive
  view of class action availability than its federal counterpart.â€); McGann v.
    Mungo, 287 S.C. 561, 570, 340 S.E.2d 154, 159 (Ct. App. 1986) (relying on
  federal precedent to interpret new Rule 23 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil
  Procedure).
Rule
  23(d)(2) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure states:

	In the conduct of actions to which this rule applies,
  the court may make appropriate orders:Â  . . . (2) The court may at any time
  impose such terms as shall fairly and adequately protect the interest of the
  persons on whose behalf the action is brought or defended.Â  It may order that notice be given in such a manner as it may direct of the pendency of the
  action by the party seeking to maintain the action on behalf of the class. It
	may
    order that notice be given in such manner as it may direct of a proposed
  settlement, of entry of judgment, or any other proceedings in the action
  including notice to the absent persons that they may come in and present claims
  and defenses if they so desire. 

Rule
  23(d)(2), SCRCP (emphasis added).
In comparison, Rule 23(c)(2)(B) of the Federal Rules of
  Civil Procedure provides:

	For any class certified under Rule 23(b)(3), the court must direct to class members the best notice practicable under the circumstances,
  including individual notice to all members who can be identified through
  reasonable effort. The notice must concisely and clearly state in plain,
  easily understood language: Â the nature of the action, the definition of the
  class certified, the class claims, issues, or defenses, that a class member may
  enter an appearance through counsel if the member so desires, that the court 
	will
    exclude from the class any member who requests exclusion, stating when and
  how members may elect to be excluded, and the binding effect of a class
  judgment on class members under Rule 23(c)(3).

Fed. R. Civ. Pro. 23(c)(2)(B)
  (emphasis added).
As
  evidenced from the emphasized text, our state rule provides a trial court with
  broader discretion to make decisions regarding class notification procedures
  than the federal rule.Â  Notably, in defining a trial courtâ€™s authority our
  state rule uses the term â€œmayâ€ whereas the federal rule uses the mandatory term
  â€œmust.â€Â  Even more significant, the federal rule specifically mandates that
  class members will only be excluded from the class if the member so requests, i.e.,
  an â€œopt-outâ€ procedure.Â  Our research has revealed only two types of federal
  class action cases where the federal courts permit an â€œopt-inâ€ procedure.Â  See Wagner v. Loewâ€™s Theatres, Inc., 76 F.R.D. 23, 24 (M.D. N.C. 1977)
  (recognizing that class action suits pursuant to the Fair Labor Standards Act
  and the Age Discrimination in Employment Act provide for statutory â€œopt-inâ€
  class action); Watkins v. Milliken & Co., 613 F. Supp. 408, 418
  (W.D. N.C. 1984) (noting that Rule 23(c) of the Federal Rules of Civil
  Procedure provides for â€œopt-outâ€ class action whereas the Fair Labor Standards
  Act allows as class members only those who â€œopt inâ€).
In
  contrast, our state rule has no similar provision. Nor has this court
  specifically spoken on the issue. Therefore, Judge Young had no guidance in
  determining the appropriate notification method. 

	Â As
  explained by Professor Flanagan:Â  
	Rule 23(d) is not exhaustive.Â  The court has inherent power to
  manage the class action and may enter any appropriate order.Â  One important
  issue not covered by the rule is the procedure for determining who is bound by
  a class action.Â  Federal Rule 23 allows only those who are members of a Rule 23(b)(3)
  class action in which common questions predominate, the option of electing not
  to be bound by the class action.Â  Class members must be notified of this right
  and must affirmatively elect not to be bound.Â  Members of a Rule 23(b)(1) or
  (b)(2) class actions are not given the option of staying out of the class
  action.
	The South Carolina Rule leaves to the courtâ€™s discretion the
  method of determining how class members elect to be bound.Â  In some actions,
  particularly those involving only injunctive relief, no procedure may be
  necessary.Â  In other cases, where common questions predominate, the court may
  use the federal approach of binding the members unless they opt-out, or
  alternately requiring an affirmative election to be bound.

Flanagan, James F., South Carolina Civil Procedure 192-93 (2d ed. 1996).
Despite the
  implicit permission in the rule for an â€œopt-inâ€ notification procedure, our
  appellate courts have not recognized this method and have clearly expressed a
  preference for the â€œopt-outâ€ procedure.Â  For example, this Court has stated:

	Thus,
  in order to provide minimal due process, absent class plaintiffs:
	must
  receive notice plus an opportunity to be heard and participate in the
  litigation, whether in person or through counsel. The notice must be the best
  practicable, â€œreasonably calculated, under all the circumstances, to apprise
  interested parties of the pendency of the action and afford them an opportunity
  to present their objections.â€ . . . The notice should describe the action and
  the plaintiffsâ€™ rights in it. Additionally, . . . due process requires at a
  minimum that an absent plaintiff be provided with an opportunity to remove
  himself from the class by executing and returning an â€œopt outâ€ or â€œrequest for
  exclusionâ€ form to the court. Finally, the Due Process Clause of course
  requires that the named plaintiff at all times adequately represent the
  interests of the absent class members.
	Id. at
  812, 105 S.Ct. 2965 (citations
  omitted). Â If the due process requirements of (1) notice; (2) an opportunity to
  be heard; (3) an opportunity to â€œopt out;â€ and (4) adequate representation are
  met, the foreign court properly asserts personal jurisdiction over the absent
  class plaintiffs. Accordingly, those plaintiffs who elect not to opt out are
  bound by the foreign courtâ€™s judgment.

Hospitality Mgmt. Assocs. v.
  Shell Oil Co.,
  356 S.C. 644, 654, 591 S.E.2d 611, 616 (2004) (quoting Phillips Petroleum
    Co. v. Shutts, 472 U.S. 797, 812 (1985)) (discussing extent of collateral
  review of due process safeguards for absent class members to a class action
  settlement in foreign jurisdiction).[8]
Moreover,
  this Court has stated, â€œSouth Carolina Rule of Civil Procedure 23(d)(2) gives
  the circuit court the broad power to â€˜impose such terms as shall fairly and
  adequately protect the interest of the persons on whose behalf the action is
  brought or defended.â€™â€Â  Eldridge v. City of Greenwood, 308 S.C. 125,
  127, 417 S.E.2d 532, 534 (1992) (quoting Rule 23(d)(2), SCRCP).Â  â€œThe power to
  issue an order which the court, in its discretion, believes is necessary to
  curtail the opportunities for abuse of the judicial system in class actions is
  not without bounds.Â  Eldridge, 308 S.C. at 127, 417 S.E.2d at 534.Â  â€œThe
  specific grants of power in Rule 23(d), SCRCP are directed towards notifying
  the absent parties of the pending litigation.â€Â  Id.Â  The discretion
  granted by Rule 23(d)(2) to determine how absent parties are notified of
  a pending action does not include the discretion to determine if a member of
  the class will be a party to the action.Â  It is inherent in class-action
  litigation that every member of the class is a party.Â  The remaining question
  is whether or not each party will present a claim or a defense. 
In
  our view, the â€œopt-inâ€ procedure is not contemplated by the notice provision of
  Rule 23. The â€œopt-inâ€ procedure is more far reaching than simply notifying
  putative class members of the pending action. It also determines the class and
  may even re-define it.Â  Moreover, we believe the elimination of the putative
  class members effectively denies those individuals a trial by jury.
Furthermore, we
  believe the implementation of the â€œopt-inâ€ procedure effectively converts the
  previously certified class action into an ersatz form of permissive joinder
  under Rule 20 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.[9] To do so eviscerates Rule 23 class actions. Â Rule 23 specifically
  requires that the court find, before certifying the class, that the classÂ  is
  so numerous that joinder is impracticable. Thus, Rule 20 joinder and Rule 23
  class actions should not co-exist.
The careful reading
  of Rules 20 and 23 together leads to the conclusion that â€œopt-inâ€ class actions
  should not be allowed. This prohibition cannot be avoided by use of an â€œopt-inâ€
  notice procedure. Â The â€œopt-inâ€ class action and the â€œopt-inâ€ notice procedure
  are a distinction in name only, the practical effect is the same.
After
  much consideration, we come to the conclusion that an â€œopt-outâ€ notification
  procedure is the proper method to be offered to putative class members in the
  instant case and future class action cases.Â  We further take this opportunity
  to specifically reject the use of an â€œopt-inâ€ procedure.Â  Taken to its logical
  extreme, the â€œopt-inâ€ procedure undermines the due process reasoning of Rule 23
  and essentially amounts to de facto decertification of a class. Â 
Specifically,
  as the text of Rule 23(d)(2) states, a court in managing a class action suit
  should issue orders that â€œfairly and adequately protect the interest of the
  persons on whose behalf the action is brought or defended.â€Â  By implementing an
  â€œopt-inâ€ procedure, we believe a court is making misperceived judicial economy
  paramount to the interests of putative class members.Â  For example, if, as in
  the instant case, limited insurance funds are available to cover claims,
  potential class members who do not participate in the class would not be
  compensated because the limited funds may be exhausted in the action.Â  Â Furthermore,
  potential members of the class may be precluded from bringing their claims due
  to statute of limitation problems.Â  Because class action litigation is intended
  to effectively litigate a large number of claims through a representative
  party, a requirement that parties â€œopt-inâ€ will undoubtedly limit the size of the
  class and, therefore, undermines the purpose of a class action suit.[10] 
Although
  we recognize that class action suits are complex and laborious for all involved
  parties, this fact alone is not sufficient to utilize a notification procedure
  that effectively eviscerates class action status.Â  Accordingly, we hold Judge
  Young erred in ordering an â€œopt-inâ€ notification procedure.
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, we dismiss the appeals of Judge Dennisâ€™s class certification
  orders as interlocutory.Â  Because we adopt the â€œopt-outâ€ class action and
  notification procedure as the exclusive method of class action litigation in
  this state, we reverse Judge Youngâ€™s order and remand for further proceedings
  consistent with this opinion.
DISMISSED
  IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J.,
MOORE and WALLER, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent. The majority holds that the
  circuit courtâ€™s interlocutory order utilizing the â€œopt-inâ€ class certification
  procedure is immediately appealable under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330(2) (1976)
  because it is an order affecting the mode of trial.Â  I disagree: the â€œmode of
  trialâ€ exception to the general rule that only final orders are appealable is
  confined to orders which abridge a partyâ€™s constitutional right to trial by
  jury.Â  E.g., Flagstar Corp. v. Royal Surplus Lines, 341 S.C. 68,
  533 S.E.2d 331 (2000); Pelfry v. Bank of Greer, 270 S.C. 691, 244 S.E.2d
  315 (1978).Â  I would therefore dismiss both appeals.Â  Knowles v. Standard
    Savings and Loan Assâ€™n., 274 S.C. 58, 261 S.E.2d 49 (1979) (dismissing an
  interlocutory appeal from a class certification order holding such an order
  â€œdoes not involve substantial or essential legal rights which require attention
  prior to final judgmentâ€).
Although the issue
  is not properly before us, I note my disagreement with the majorityâ€™s decision
  on the merits as well as with its procedural ruling.Â  Without question, the
  circuit court has discretion to create an â€œopt-inâ€ class under Rule 23(d), SCRCP, and while we have never directly addressed the propriety of the â€œopt-inâ€
  class, we have never disapproved of the procedure.Â  See Tilley v.
    Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 585 S.E.2d 292 (2003) (approving timing of
  notice to persons eligible to join the class).Â  Moreover, I am at a loss to
  understand the majorityâ€™s holding that an â€œopt-inâ€ class somehow runs afoul of
  Rule 20(a), SCRCP, the permissive joinder provision.Â  The first prerequisite
  for class certification is a finding that the class is so numerous that joinder
  is not practicable.Â  Assuming that criterion is satisfied, whether the class
  proceeds as â€œopt-inâ€ or â€œopt-out,â€ each potential class member has the right to
  determine whether to participate in the law suit, and thus the same â€œersatzâ€
  joinder problem exists under either scenario.
None of the
  interlocutory orders sought to be appealed are immediately appealable under Â§
  14-3-330.Â  I would dismiss the cross-appeals.


[1]Â Â  Charleston Gypsum Dealers and Supply Co., Inc., sold
  the Parex synthetic stucco that was applied to the exterior of Salmonsenâ€™s
  residence in 1994.Â  On May 15, 1995, Charleston Gypsum sold its business and name
  to CSR America.Â  Subsequently, Charleston Gypsum changed its name to CGD, Inc.Â 
  After all known creditors were paid, the sales proceeds were distributed to
  CGD, Inc.â€™s shareholders over the next few years.Â  In 1999, the corporation was
  administratively dissolved.Â  
[2]Â Â  Section 14-3-330(2) states:

	The
  Supreme Court shall have appellate jurisdiction for correction of errors of law
  in law cases, and shall review upon appeal:
	(2) An order affecting a substantial right made in an action when
  such order (a) in effect determines the action and prevents a judgment from
  which an appeal might be taken or discontinues the action,
  (b) grants or refuses a new trial or (c) strikes out an answer or any part
  thereof or any pleading in any action.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  14-3-330(2) (1977 & Supp. 2007).
[3]Â  This rule was enacted pursuant to the express
  authority of 28 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1292 (2007), a statute providing for federal courts
  of appeal to review interlocutory decisions.
[4]Â Â  We note there were changes made to the Federal
  Rules of Civil Procedure effective December 1, 2007.Â  Because these changes are
  only intended to be stylistic, these amendments do not affect the issues in
  this appeal.Â  Accordingly, we cite to the version of Rule 23 which was in
  effect at the time of the initiation of this litigation.
[5] Â â€œAlthough
  we will not generally accept matters on a writ of certiorari that can be
  entertained in the trial court or on appeal, a writ of certiorari may be issued
  when exceptional circumstances exist.â€ In re Breast Implant Prod. Liab.
    Litig., 331 S.C. 540, 543 n.2, 503 S.E.2d 445, 447 n.2 (1998).
[6] Â At oral argument CGD agreed that the â€œopt-inâ€
  procedure affected the mode of trial.
[7] Â It should be noted that Judge Youngâ€™s order did not
  decertify the class; however, it did designate it as an â€œopt-inâ€ class action.
[8]Â  Interestingly, the dissent concurred without opinion
  in Hospitality Management Associates.Â  As evident from the above-quoted
  language, the unanimous Court unequivocally approved of the â€œopt-outâ€ procedure
  as the preferred procedure and clearly indicated that this procedure comports
  with the requirements of due process.Â  Thus, we are perplexed by the dissent
  given it represents a fundamental reversal on this issue.
Furthermore, the
  dissentâ€™s reference to Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 585
  S.E.2d 292 (2003), is unavailing.Â  In Tilley, this Court approved of the
  trial courtâ€™s delaying the actual mailing of the class notice until
  after certain issues were resolved on appeal.Â  This decision had absolutely
  nothing to do with â€œopt-inâ€ class actions.
[9]Â Â  Rule 20 provides in relevant part:

	
		
			a) 
			Permissive
  Joinder. All persons may join in
  one action as plaintiffs if they assert any right to relief jointly, severally,
  or in the alternative in respect of or arising out of the same transaction,
  occurrence, or series of transactions or occurrences and if any question of law
  or fact common to all these persons will arise in the action. Â All persons may
  be joined in one action as defendants if there is asserted against them
  jointly, severally, or in the alternative, any right to relief in respect of or
  arising out of the same transaction, occurrence, or series of transactions or
  occurrences and if any question of law or fact common to all defendants will
  arise in the action. Â A plaintiff or defendant need not be interested in
  obtaining or defending against all the relief demanded. Judgment may be given
  for one or more of the plaintiffs according to their respective rights to
  relief, and against one or more defendants according to their respective
  liabilities.
		
	

Rule
  20(a), SCRCP.
[10]Â Â  One commentator has explained the negative effects
  of an â€œopt-inâ€ procedure as follows:

	[T]he
  opt-in procedure is . . . a
  very effective means of diminishing the size of a class, because an affirmative
  act by an individual is always less likely than mere inaction and hence
  presents certain dangers. Requiring class members to insert themselves into the
  suit will result inevitably in smaller classes, unrelated to the magnitude of
  the harm done or the merits of the case. Â In addition to its unfairness,
  unnecessary reduction of class size negates the perceived benefits of class
  actions as efficient and economic means of litigation, since those who fail to
  opt in could bring their own suits, thereby multiplying cases where one would
  do.

Kleiner
  v. First Natâ€™l Bank of Atlanta, 751 F.2d 1193, 1202 n.19 (11th Cir. 1985) (quoting Note, Reforming
    Federal Class Action Procedure: An Analysis of the Justice Department Proposal,
  16 Harv.J.Legis. 543, 571-72 (1979)).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				USAA Property
      and Casualty Insurance Company, Appellant/Respondent,
				v.
				Deborah J.
      Clegg, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Allison T. Clegg; Elliot
      M. Lambrecht; and Douglas A. Lambrecht, Defendants
				of whom
				Douglas A.
      Lambrecht is Respondent/Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26476
Heard March 6, 2008 - Filed April 28, 2008Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				William
  O. Sweeny, III and William R. Calhoun, Jr., both of Sweeny, Wingate &
  Barrow, of Columbia, for Appellant-Respondent.
				John
  E. North, Jr. and Pamela K. Black, both of North & Black, of Beaufort, for
  Respondent-Appellant.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  In this declaratory judgment
  action, USAA Property and Casualty Insurance Company (â€œUSAAâ€), appeals the
  circuit courtâ€™s order granting partial summary judgment in favor of Douglas A.
  Lambrecht on his claim that USAA had a duty to defend him against a wrongful
  death and survival action arising out of an accident caused by his non-resident,
  emancipated son while driving a â€œnon-ownedâ€ automobile.Â  Lambrecht, in a
  cross-appeal, contends this Court is without jurisdiction to review the
  appeal.Â  We certified the appeal from the Court of Appeals.Â  We reverse.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On January 9, 2002, Lambrechtâ€™s nineteen-year-old son,
  Elliott M. Lambrecht (â€œElliottâ€), while driving with a suspended license, was
  involved in a single-vehicle accident that resulted in the death of his
  passenger, Allison T. Clegg.Â  At the time of the accident, Elliott was not a
  resident of Lambrechtâ€™s home and was driving a 1994 Mazda, which was owned by
  Elliott and not listed as a covered automobile on Lambrechtâ€™s insurance policy
  with USAA.Â  
Subsequently,
  Deborah J. Clegg, Cleggâ€™s mother and personal representative of her estate,
  filed a wrongful death and survival action which named Elliott and Lambrecht as
  defendants.Â  Based on her belief that Lambrecht owned the 1994 Mazda, Clegg
  asserted causes of action for negligent entrustment and negligence on the
  grounds that Lambrecht knew his son:Â  (1) was driving without a valid South Carolina driverâ€™s license; and (2) had a history of numerous traffic violations involving
  excessive speed. Â Shortly after the initial filing, Clegg amended her Complaints.Â 
  In the Amended Complaints, Clegg named three other defendants[1] and characterized Lambrecht as the â€œde factoâ€ owner of the 1994 Mazda.Â Â  
In response, USAA denied Lambrechtâ€™s request to defend him in the underlying lawsuits. Â USAA then filed
  a declaratory judgment action seeking a determination by the circuit court that
  there was no coverage under Lambrechtâ€™s policy and, thus, it owed no duty to
  defend.Â  Specifically, USAA claimed the insurance policy in effect at the time
  of the accident did not name Elliott as an insured and did not list the 1994
  Mazda as a covered vehicle.[2]Â Â 
  USAA also relied on the fact that Elliott owned the 1994 Mazda and was not a
  resident relative at the time of the accident.Â  Based on these allegations,
  USAA believed it did not have a duty to defend Lambrecht or Elliott given there
  were no provisions of the policy which would render coverage for the accident.
Lambrecht filed an
  Answer and Counterclaim in which he alleged that USAA was required to defend
  him in the underlying action as well as reimburse him for the attorneyâ€™s fees
  and costs of defending the lawsuits and USAAâ€™s declaratory judgment action.Â 
  Lambrecht alleged he was a â€œcovered personâ€ under the terms of the policy and
  that USAA owed him a duty to defend based on the following policy language:Â 
  â€œWe will pay damages for BI or PD for which any covered person becomes legally
  liable because of an auto accident.â€[3]Â 
  As a result, Lambrecht filed a motion for partial summary judgment.Â  
After a hearing on Lambrechtâ€™s motion, the circuit court issued an order on April 8, 2005, granting
  partial summary judgment in favor of Lambrecht. Â The court prefaced its order
  by noting the parties agreed the facts were undisputed and the motion presented
  a question of law â€œwith regard to the construction of the policy of insurance
  issued by USAA to Lambrecht.â€Â  In the recitation of the facts, the court
  specifically noted that at the time of the accident:Â  (1) Elliott was nineteen
  years old and no longer a member of Lambrechtâ€™s household; (2) the 1994 Mazda
  was owned by Elliott; and (3) the 1994 Mazda was not identified as a covered
  automobile in the Declarations page of the policy. 
The court framed
  the issue before it as follows:Â  â€œwhether [the allegations] even if ultimately
  proven to be legally and factually baseless, trigger USAAâ€™s obligation to
  defend Lambrecht in the Underlying Actions.â€Â  Relying on the language of the
  policy and decisions from other jurisdictions, the court answered this question
  in the affirmative.Â  With respect to the policy, the court found â€œ[t]he
  unambiguous language of the Policy provides coverage for Lambrecht if the
  claims against him arise from any auto accident, not just one in which he was a
  driver, and was the result of the â€˜ownership, maintenance, or useâ€™ of â€˜any
  auto,â€™ not just those automobiles insured under the Policy.â€ 
On May 26, 2005,
  USAA filed a motion for reconsideration of the April 8, 2005 order.Â  USAA
  explained the filing of its motion was belated because it did not receive
  notice of entry of the order until May 16, 2005. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Lambrecht objected to
  the motion as untimely.Â  In support of his objection, Lambrecht filed an
  affidavit from his attorney and an accompanying facsimile transmittal sheet
  which indicated that Lambrechtâ€™s attorney had faxed a letter to USAAâ€™s counsel
  on April 19, 2005, which stated that he had received a copy of the circuit
  courtâ€™s order.Â  
After a hearing on
  the motion,[4] the circuit court issued an order on August 22, 2005, in which it found USAAâ€™s
  motion for reconsideration was timely filed.Â  As to the substantive issues, the
  Court affirmed its previous order but modified the basis for its decision.[5] 
Both parties
  appealed the circuit courtâ€™s order to the Court of Appeals.Â  We certified the
  appeal from the Court of Appeals.Â  
Although the
  parties in their cross-appeals raise multiple issues, we believe there are
  essentially two questions before the Court:Â  (1) whether this Court has jurisdiction
  to review the appeal?; and (2) whether the circuit court erred in finding USAA
  had a duty to defend Lambrecht in the underlying wrongful death and survival
  actions? [6] 
I.  JURISDICTION
In his cross-appeal, Lambrecht contends the circuit
  court erred in finding USAAâ€™s motion for reconsideration was timely given it
  was filed more than ten days after entry of the April 8, 2005 order.Â  If the
  motion is found to have been untimely, Lambrecht asserts the circuit court was
  without jurisdiction to hear the motion.Â  As a result, Lambrecht claims this
  Court, in turn, is without jurisdiction to review the appeal on the ground the
  time was not tolled for USAA to file its Notice of Appeal. 
â€œRule 203(b), SCACR, requires a party to
  serve his notice of appeal within thirty days after receiving written notice of
  the entry of a final order or judgment, and failure to do so divests this court
  of subject matter jurisdiction and results in dismissal of the appeal.â€Â  Canal
    Ins. Co. v. Caldwell, 338 S.C. 1, 4, 524 S.E.2d 416, 418 (Ct. App. 1999).Â 
  â€œThe requirement of service of the notice of appeal is jurisdictional, i.e.,
  if a party misses the deadline, the
  appellate court lacks jurisdiction to consider the appeal and has no authority
  or discretion to â€˜rescueâ€™ the delinquent party by extending or ignoring the
  deadline for service of the notice.â€ Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp.,
  361 S.C. 9, 14-15, 602 S.E.2d 772, 775 (2004). Â 
â€œA timely post-trial motion, including a motion to alter or amend
  the judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, stays the time for an appeal for
  all parties until receipt of written notice of entry of the order granting or
  denying such motion.â€ Id. at 15, 602 S.E.2d at 775 (citing Rule
  203(b)(1), SCACR, Rules 50(e), 52(c), and 59(f), SCRCP).Â  â€œA motion under Rule
  59(e) is timely if it is â€˜served not later than 10 days after receipt of
  written notice of the entry of the order.â€™ Â If a timely motion is made pursuant
  to Rule 59, the time for appeal runs from the receipt of written notice of
  entry of the order disposing of the motion.â€Â  Coward Hund Constr. Co. v.
    Ball Corp., 336 S.C. 1, 3, 518 S.E.2d 56, 57 (Ct. App. 1999).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Strictly
  applying the above-outlined rules of civil and appellate procedure, there is
  evidence to support Lambrechtâ€™s assertion. However, for this Court to dismiss
  the appeal for lack of jurisdiction, it would have to essentially reject the
  circuit courtâ€™s implicit credibility determination of USAAâ€™s counsel and find
  that counsel made a false representation to the circuit court regarding notice
  of entry of the order.Â  
In response to
  Lambrechtâ€™s assertion that USAAâ€™s motion to reconsider was untimely, USAAâ€™s
  counsel submitted a letter to the circuit court in which she claimed she did
  not receive notice of entry of the final order until May 16, 2005, when
  Lambrechtâ€™s counsel contacted her.Â  After receiving this notice, USAAâ€™s counsel
  claimed she filed the motion for reconsideration on May 26, 2005, within the
  requisite ten-day time period.Â  Presumably, USAAâ€™s counsel was being truthful
  when she made this representation to the circuit court. See Rule 407(1),
  SCACR (â€œA lawyer, being a member of the legal profession, is a representative
  of clients, an officer of the legal system and a public citizen having special
  responsibility for the quality of justice.â€); Rule 3.3(a)(1)(â€œA lawyer shall
  not knowingly make a false statement of fact or law to a tribunal or fail to
  correct a false statement of material fact or law previously made to the
  tribunal by the lawyer.â€); Rule 4.1(a)(â€œIn the course of representing a client
  a lawyer shall not knowingly make a false statement of material fact or law to
  a third person.â€); Rule
  8.4(d)(â€œIt is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct
  involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation.â€). Â 
Because there is no
  record of the hearing, this Court is unable to determine whether USAAâ€™s
  counselâ€™s representations to the circuit court were under oath.Â  Furthermore,
  the circuit courtâ€™s order is silent regarding the basis for its decision
  finding that USAAâ€™s motion for reconsideration was timely filed.Â  In light of
  this procedural posture, it was incumbent upon Lambrecht to file a motion
  pursuant to Rule 59(e) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure to
  request that the circuit court provide specific factual findings for its
  decision.Â  See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d
  122, 124 (1991) (holding that where a trial court does not explicitly rule on
  an argument raised, and appellant makes no Rule 59(e)
  motion to obtain a ruling, the appellate court may not address the issue); Floyd
    v. Floyd, 365 S.C. 56, 73, 615 S.E.2d 465, 474 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œWhen a
  trial judge makes a general ruling on an issue, but does
  not address the specific argument raised by the appellant
  and the appellant does not make a motion to alter or amend pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to obtain a ruling on
  the argument, the appellate court cannot consider the argument on appeal.â€).
Without explicit
  findings of fact by the circuit court, our decision can only be based on the
  implicit credibility determination of the circuit court.Â  Deferring to the
  circuit court, we find USAAâ€™s counsel was credible in explaining her delay in
  filing the motion for reconsideration.Â  See Reed v. Ozmint, 374
  S.C. 19, 24, 647 S.E.2d 209, 211 (2007) (noting the circuit court judge, who saw and
  heard the witnesses, is in a better position to evaluate their credibility and
  assign comparative weight to their testimony).Â  Based on the record before us,
  we decline to reverse the decision of the circuit court.
As a result, we hold
  USAAâ€™s motion to reconsider and Notice of Appeal were timely.Â  In turn, this
  Court has jurisdiction to review USAAâ€™s appeal.
II.  DUTY TO DEFEND
Having found this Court has jurisdiction to review
  USAAâ€™s appeal, the question becomes whether the circuit court erred in granting
  partial summary judgment in favor of Lambrecht and finding that USAA had a duty
  to defend Lambrecht against the underlying wrongful death and survival actions.Â  
A. Standard of Review
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, appellate
  courts apply the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP, which provides that summary judgment is proper
  when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is
  entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Â Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Helms Realty,
    Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 340, 611 S.E.2d 485, 488 (2005); Fleming
      v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002). Â On appeal from an
  order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will
  review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the
  evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below. Willis v.
    Wu, 362 S.C. 146, 151, 607 S.E.2d 63, 65 (2004).
â€œSummary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry
  into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.â€ Middleborough Horizontal Prop. Regime Council of Co-Owners v.
    Montedison S.p.A., 320 S.C. 470, 479, 465 S.E.2d 765, 771 (Ct. App. 1995)
  (citing Baugus v. Wessinger, 303 S.C. 412, 401 S.E.2d 169 (1991)). Â â€œEven
  when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the
  conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them, summary
  judgment should be denied.â€ Nelson v. Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n, 362 S.C. 1, 5, 605 S.E.2d 744, 746 (Ct. App. 2004). Â â€œHowever,
  when plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds
  cannot differ, summary judgment should be granted.â€ Ellis
    v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 518, 595 S.E.2d 817, 822 (Ct. App. 2004).
B.  Insurerâ€™s
  Duty to Defend
In Sloan
  Construction Company, Inc.. v. Central National Insurance Company of Omaha,
  this Court explained the theoretical underpinnings of an insurerâ€™s duty to
  defend:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

	A
  liability insurance policy contains two insuring provisions of major
  significance: one, providing for the payment by the insurer of sums the insured
  shall become obligated to pay, the other providing, in substance, for the
  defense of any suit alleging bodily injury or property damage and seeking
  damages payable under the terms of the policy. The latter clause also provides,
  as a rule, that such a defense will be furnished even if any of the allegations
  of the suit are groundless, false or fraudulent.
	The duty to defend is separate and
  distinct from the obligation to pay a judgment rendered against the insured. 
	American
    Casualty Co. v. Howard, 187 F.2d 322, 327 (4th Cir. 1951). Although these
  duties are related in the sense that the duty to defend depends on an initial
  or apparent potential liability to satisfy the judgment, the duty to defend
  exists regardless of the insurerâ€™s ultimate liability to the insured.
	*
  * *
	Indemnity
  contemplates merely the payment of money. The agreement to defend contemplates
  the rendering of services.

Sloan Constr.
  Co. v. Central Natâ€™l Ins. Co. of Omaha, 269 S.C. 183, 186-87, 236 S.E.2d 818, 820 (1977) (citations
  omitted).
Although
  an insurerâ€™s duty to defend is separate and distinct from its obligation to pay
  a judgment, the two are in a sense interrelated.Â  If the facts alleged in the
  complaint against an insured fail to bring a claim within policy coverage, an
  insurer has no duty to defend.Â  S.C. Med. Malpractice Liab. Ins.
    Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n v. Ferry, 291 S.C. 460, 463, 354 S.E.2d 378,
  380 (1987). Â â€œAccordingly, the allegations
  of the complaint determine the insurerâ€™s duty to defend.â€ Â Id.; B.L.G. Enters., Inc. v. First Fin. Ins.
    Co., 334 S.C. 529, 535,
  514 S.E.2d 327, 330 (1999) (â€œIt is well settled that an insurerâ€™s duty to
  defend is based on the allegations of the underlying complaint.â€). Â â€œA
  liability insurer must defend any suit alleging bodily injury or property
  damage seeking damages payable under the terms of the policy.â€ B.L.G. Enters.,
    Inc, 334 S.C. at 535, 514 S.E.2d at 330. â€œHowever, an insurer has no duty
  to defend an insured where the damage was caused for a reason unambiguously
  excluded under the policy.â€Â  Id. 
â€œInsurance
  policies are subject to the general rules of contract construction.â€Â  B.L.G.
    Enters., Inc, 334 S.C. at 535, 514 S.E.2d at 330.Â  â€œCourts must enforce,
  not write, contracts of insurance, and their language must be given its plain,
  ordinary and popular meaning.â€ Sloan Constr. Co., 269 S.C. at 185, 236
  S.E.2d at 819. â€œWhen a contract is unambiguous, clear, and explicit, it must be
  construed according to the terms the parties have used.â€Â  B.L.G. Enters.,
    Inc, 334 S.C. at 535, 514 S.E.2d at 330.Â  â€œAmbiguous or conflicting terms
  in an insurance policy must be construed liberally in favor of the insured and
  strictly against the insurer.â€ Â Diamond State Ins. Co. v. Homestead Indus.,
    Inc., 318 S.C. 231, 236, 456 S.E.2d 912, 915 (1995).
Applying the foregoing to the facts of the instant case, we
  believe for several reasons the circuit court erred in finding USAA had a duty
  to defend Lambrecht against the underlying wrongful death and survival suits.Â  Initially,
  we find the circuit court overlooked an analytical step.Â  In our view, the
  circuit court should have first determined whether the allegations in Cleggâ€™s
  Complaints brought the claims within policy coverage.Â  Instead, the circuit
  court omitted this step and considered factual allegations presented to it at
  the summary judgment stage that were not part of the Complaints.Â  The absence
  of this analysis is significant because the circuit court ordered USAA to
  reimburse Lambrecht for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs in defending the initial
  filing of the lawsuit as well as defending against USAAâ€™s declaratory judgment
  motion.Â  As will be discussed, we hold USAA did not have a duty to defend from
  the onset of the litigation.
An analysis of this issue is dependent upon a comparison of the
  relevant USAA policy provisions with the allegations in Cleggâ€™s Complaint.Â  

	The policy provisions at issue are as follows:

INSURING AGREEMENT

	We will pay damages for BI or PD for which any covered
  person becomes legally liable because of an auto accident.Â  We will
  settle or defend, as we consider appropriate, any claim or suit asking
  for these damages.Â  Our duty to settle or defend ends when our limit of
  liability for these coverages has been paid or tendered.Â  We have no
  duty to defend any suit or settle any claim for BI or PD not
  covered under this policy.

EXCLUSIONS

	
		
			B. 
			 We do not provide Liability Coverage for the
  ownership, maintenance, or use of:Â  (2) Any vehicle, other than your covered
    auto that is owned by you, or furnished or available for your regular use. 
			
		
	

DEFINITIONS

	
		
			A. 
			 You and your refer to the â€œnamed
  insuredâ€ shown in the Declarations and spouse if a resident of the same
  household.
 
		
		
			E.  
			 Family member means a person related to you by blood,
  marriage, or adoption who is a resident of your household.Â  This
  includes a ward or foster child.
 
		
		
			L.  
			 Your covered auto means:
		
	
	
		1.     Any vehicle shown in
  the Declarations.
	

[A] covered person as used [in the Liability Coverage
  Section] means:

	
		
			1. 
			 You or any family member for the
  ownership, maintenance, or use of any auto or trailer.
		
	

Here, Cleggâ€™s initial Complaint and Amended Complaints
  alleged causes of action against Lambrecht for negligent entrustment and negligence[7] based on Cleggâ€™s belief that
  Lambrecht was the owner or â€œde factoâ€ owner of the 1994 Mazda.Â  Taking these
  allegations as true, section B(2) of the USAA policy specifically excluded
  coverage.Â  That provision explicitly excluded coverage for the â€œownershipâ€ of a
  vehicle other than Lambrechtâ€™s covered automobiles.Â  Because the 1994 Mazda was
  not listed in the Declarations section of the policy, it did not constitute a
  covered automobile.Â  Accordingly, based solely on the allegations in Cleggâ€™s
  Complaints, the USAA policy did not provide coverage.Â  Therefore, although USAA
  has a continuing potential duty to defend based on its contractual relationship
  with Lambrecht, it was not required to defend Lambrecht against this underlying
  lawsuit given the duty was limited by the coverage outlined in the insurance
  policy.
Furthermore, to the extent Lambrecht argues that this issue is
  controlled entirely by the â€œInsuring Agreementâ€ provision, we find this
  assertion to be without merit.Â  In our view, this policy provision cannot be
  read in isolation.Â  Instead, the allegations in the Complaint must be applied
  to the policy in its entirety, which necessarily includes the exclusions
  section.Â  See Falkosky v. Allstate Ins. Co., 311 S.C. 369, 372,
  429 S.E.2d 194, 196 (Ct. App.), affâ€™d as modified, 312 S.C. 210, 439
  S.E.2d 836 (1993) (recognizing an insurer has no duty to defend where liability is
  excluded from coverage); Snakenberg v. Hartford Cas. Ins. Co., 299 S.C.
  164, 168, 383 S.E.2d 2, 4 (Ct. App. 1989) (finding insurer had no duty to
  defend where policy expressly excluded coverage for damages alleged in the
  Complaint).
Although
  the cases addressing an insurerâ€™s duty to defend generally limit this duty to
  whether the allegations in a Complaint are sufficient to bring the claims
  within the coverage of an insurance policy, an insurerâ€™s duty to defend is not
  strictly controlled by the allegations in Complaint. Â Instead, the duty to
  defend may also be determined by facts outside of the complaint that are known
  by the insurer. Â See BP Oil Co. v. Federated Mut. Ins. Co., 329
  S.C. 631, 638, 496 S.E.2d 35, 39 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œAlthough the determination
  of an insurerâ€™s duty to defend is based upon the allegations in a complaint . .
  . in some jurisdictions, the duty to defend will be measured by facts outside
  of the complaint that are known by the insurer.â€).Â  The instant case provides
  such a scenario given USAA presented additional facts at the declaratory
  judgment stage that were not initially known to Clegg at the time she filed her
Complaints.
Turning to the actual analysis in the circuit courtâ€™s order, we
  find the court erred in ruling that the USAA policy provided coverage for the
  1994 Mazda when it was undisputed by the parties that Lambrechtâ€™s emancipated
  adult son, who was not a resident relative, was the owner of the vehicle. 
First, under the terms of the policy, neither Lambrecht nor his
  son was a â€œcovered person.â€Â  Because Elliott did not reside in Lambrechtâ€™s
  household, he could not be considered a â€œcovered personâ€ in light of the fact
  that he was not a â€œfamily member.â€Â  Given Lambrecht admitted that he did not
  â€œown,â€ â€œmaintain,â€ or â€œuseâ€ the 1994 Mazda at the time of the accident, he also
  did not meet the definition of a â€œcovered person.â€Â  
Secondly, even if Lambrecht could be deemed a â€œcovered
  person,â€ we disagree with the circuit courtâ€™s finding that he could be
  potentially liable for a claim of negligent entrustment arising from the
  negligent use of a noncovered automobile by someone other than the insured.Â  Â A
  review of the cases cited by the circuit court reveals that they do not support
  the courtâ€™s holding. Â In three of the cited cases, parents were found to be
  liable for damages arising out of their childrenâ€™s negligent driving.Â  See Brown v. Champeau, 537 So. 2d 1120, 1122 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1989)(en
  banc) (holding insurance policy covered mother, who became statutorily liable
  for her minor sonâ€™s driving where she signed for his license application, for damages
  resulting from her sonâ€™s negligence while driving his own vehicle); Eason v.
    Fin. Indem. Co., 721 So. 2d 528, 530 (La. Ct. App. 1998) (finding insurance
  policy provided coverage for parents who were held vicariously liable by
  statute for damages resulting from their minor childâ€™s negligent driving;
  noting, under policy, that mother would not have been responsible for â€œmajor
  childâ€ as a â€œfamily memberâ€); Scott v. Am. Standard Ins. Co. of Wisconsin,
  392 N.W.2d 461, 464 (Wisc. Ct. App. 1986) (ruling insurance policy provided
  coverage for mother who was statutorily liable for her minor sonâ€™s driving
  negligence where she sponsored her minor son in order to allow him to obtain a
  driverâ€™s license). Â Â We find these cases are distinguishable given the child at
  issue was a minor and the parents were statutorily liable for damages caused by
  their childrenâ€™s negligence.Â  In the instant case, Elliott was an emancipated
  child at the time of the accident and there is no statutorily-imposed
  obligation for Lambrecht to be responsible for damages caused by Elliottâ€™s negligence.Â 
  Finally, the fourth case relied on by the circuit court is inapposite.Â  Hertz
    Corp. v. Amerisure Ins. Co., 627 So. 2d 22, 23 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 1993) (holding
  insurance policy provided coverage for insured who was legally liable for a
  friendâ€™s negligent driving under the stateâ€™s dangerous instrumentality doctrine
  where insured used his credit card to rent a vehicle for his friend).Â  Here,
  there is no comparable dangerous instrumentality statute in this state.Â 
  Furthermore, the undisputed facts established that Elliott, not Lambrecht,
  owned the vehicle involved in the accident.Â  Thus, we do not believe that
  Lambrecht could be held â€œlegally liable,â€ as required by the terms of the
  policy, for Elliottâ€™s negligence based on these cases.Â  
Additionally, there are cases from other jurisdictions in which
  the courts have held that the parent of an emancipated adult child driving a
  non-owned vehicle was not liable for the childâ€™s alleged negligent acts.Â  See Tollefson v. Am. Family Ins. Co., 226 N.W.2d 280, 284-85 (Minn. 1974) (recognizing
  that insurance policy did not provide coverage for accident of emancipated
  child, who did not reside in insuredâ€™s household and was driving a non-owned
  vehicle); see also Safeco Ins. Co. of Am. v. Parks, 19
  Cal.Rptr.3d 17, 24-28 (Cal. Ct. App. 2004) (holding insurer had no duty to
  defend minor child where she was driving a non-owned vehicle and was not a
  member of insuredâ€™s household); Crawley v. State Farm Mut. Auto Ins. Co.,
  979 P.2d 74, 80-83 (Haw. Ct. App. 1999) (finding insurer owed no duty to defend
  insured for negligent actions of minor child, who was not a resident relative,
  while driving a non-owned vehicle); Universal Underwriters Ins. Co. v. State
    Farm Auto. Ins. Co., 470 N.E.2d 1130, 1134 (Ill. App. Ct. 1984) (concluding
  insurer of minorâ€™s parents owed no duty to defend them for suits arising out of
  minor childâ€™s acts while driving a non-owned vehicle given child did not live
  with the insureds); Nichols v. Atnip, 844 S.W.2d 655, 660-63 (Tenn. Ct.
  App. 1992) (affirming summary judgment for parents of emancipated child,
  finding parents did not negligently entrust automobile to child and parents
  owed no duty to accident victims to supervise childâ€™s driving); Coop. Fire
    Ins. Assâ€™n of Vermont v. Am. Prot. Ins. Co., 599 A.2d 360, 385 (Vt. 1991)
  (holding insurer was not required to defend insured against negligent
  entrustment and supervision causes of action arising from minor childâ€™s use of
  non-covered automobile); cf. Natâ€™l Union Fire Ins. v. Carricato,
  439 S.W.2d 957, 959 (Ky. Ct. App. 1969) (finding emancipated child was covered
  under parentsâ€™ insurance policy where she lived in parentsâ€™ home and was the
  beneficial owner of the vehicle); see generally 8A Lee R. Russ, Couch
    on Insurance 3d Â§Â§ 118:21, 39 (Supp. 2007) (discussing liability coverage
  for the use of non-owned vehicles). 
III.Â  USAAâ€™s REMAINING
  ISSUES
In
  its brief, USAA raises two additional issues.Â  USAA contends the circuit court
  erred in: Â (1) imposing a duty to defend when neither a covered auto nor a covered
  person was involved in the accident because such a ruling expands automobile
  liability policies beyond what the Legislature and the Supreme Court intended;
  and (2) granting summary judgment as to whether USAA owed Respondent a defense
  and an award of costs and fees when there had not been adequate time for
  discovery in the case.Â  
Because these
  issues were neither raised to nor ruled upon by the circuit court, we find they
  were not properly preserved for our review. See B & A Dev., Inc.
    v. Georgetown County, 372 S.C. 261, 271, 641 S.E.2d 888, 894 (2007) (holding that issues must be raised and
  ruled upon in the trial court to be preserved for appellate review); Staubes
    v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (holding
  that issues must be raised and ruled upon in the trial
  court to be preserved for appellate review). Â Furthermore, in light of our decision finding USAA did not have a duty
  to defend, we decline to address USAAâ€™s remaining issues.Â  See Futch
    v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d
  591, 598 (1999) (ruling that
  an appellate court need not review remaining issues when
  disposition of prior issues is dispositive).
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, we find the circuit court correctly concluded that USAAâ€™s motion to
  reconsider was timely filed.Â  Thus, we have jurisdiction to review USAAâ€™s
  appeal.Â  As to the merits of the appeal, we reverse the decision of the circuit
  court finding USAA had a duty to defend and reimburse Lambrecht.Â  Because the
  USAA policy did not provide coverage to Lambrecht under either the allegations
  of Cleggâ€™s Complaints or the additional facts known to USAA and presented at
  the declaratory judgment stage, we hold USAA had no duty to defend and
  reimburse Lambrecht.Â  
REVERSED.
MOORE, Acting Chief Justice, WALLER, J., and Acting Justices E. C. Burnett, III and
  Aphrodite K. Konduros, concur.


[1]Â  These individuals were Elliottâ€™s relatives and
friends who also had access to the vehicle involved in the accident.Â  
[2]Â Â  The insurance policy that was in effect between
  September 20, 2001, and March 20, 2002, named Lambrecht as the insured and
  listed a 1997 BMW Z3 convertible and a 1997 Ford Explorer as covered vehicles.Â 
  Prior to the renewal of the policy on September 20, 2001, Elliott was deleted
as a named insured and the 1994 Mazda was deleted as a covered vehicle. 
[3]Â Â  In his Answer and Counterclaim, Lambrecht admitted
  that Elliott was neither a resident relative nor a named insured under the USAA
  policy.Â  He further admitted he did not â€œuseâ€ or â€œmaintainâ€ the 1994 Mazda and
  it was owned by Elliott and, thus, not listed as a covered automobile under the
  policy.Â  Additionally, Lambrecht stated that the 1994 Mazda was not owned by,
  furnished, or available for the regular use of a â€œfamily memberâ€ as defined in
the policy.
[4]Â  The circuit court conducted the hearing in his
chambers without a court reporter present.
[5]Â  A comparison of the two orders reveals that the
  circuit court deleted two paragraphs from the initial order in which it
addressed USAAâ€™s allegations that the policy specifically excluded coverage. 
[6]Â  Because the jurisdictional question is a threshold
  issue in the case, we have decided to address it first despite its order in the
  partiesâ€™ briefs.Â  In terms of the parties remaining issues, we have
  consolidated some issues and addressed some out of the â€œbriefedâ€ order in the
interest of clarity.
[7]Â Â  â€œThe
  theory of negligent entrustment provides:Â  the owner or
  one in control of the vehicle and responsible for its use who is negligent in
  entrusting it to another can be held liable for such negligent entrustment.â€ Am. Mut. Fire Ins. Co. v. Passmore, 275 S.C.
618, 621, 274 S.E.2d 416, 418 (1981) (citations omitted).
